The in-hotel dining options were a bit expensive, but the room was large and clean, the staff friendly, and the WiFi was fast. More than I'm used to paying in the States, but not shabby given the local prices.

result.name: Quo Vadis
result.address: 26-29 Dean Street, London W1D 3LL, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: The name got me here. I had obviously made some weird associations on a subconscious level with Sienkiewicz's book as I had my mind set on togas, laurels, chubby gentlemen and slender women lounging around, biting into roast piglets and apples, the epitome of gluttony. None of that. It's simple, it's elegant, it's British. So is the food. British, I mean.
Nice decor and place. Food was just OK. But, way over-priced. Sorry, but many better options around.
Believe the hype? Perhaps not. Although widely loved as one of Soho's finest "it spots", the food was just OK, and there's a dozen better places to eat within a few minutes.

Fine dining in the heart of Soho with a stained glass window setting in the building where Karl Marx wrote Das Kapital. I love the rejuvenated traditional british coastal menu as the restaurant finds itself under new management. Go for the grilled whole Mackerel with pickled gooseberries, the best fresh mackerel I've ver eaten in a restaurant.
Nice and elegant restaurant but neither the food nor the service are worth the price.

result.name: La Trompette
result.address: 5-7 Devonshire Road, Chiswick, Greater London W4 2EU, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: We made a booking at this restaurant to celebrate our girls' graduation. We had an amazing night thanks to the waiting staff. They were available for us all the time and paid attention to everything we needed. The food and the wine were extremely good and served in an attractive way.

I have eaten here before and the food and service were excellent, upon my last visit with a larger group I found we were only offered a smaller portion of the menu which was a shame as a lot of choice was then cut, the service was slow and incompetent at times, I often have plates and waiters barging into me you should not even notice the waters around you. The food was very good I have to say just it felt like the waiters were all on training the day we dined. A restaurant with a Michelin Star should do MUCH better.

Me and my partner eat here regularly, we've been to most of the major restaurants in the UK and when you compare La Trompette based on service, food, value, atmosphere and wine, it's clear that La Trompette stands out far above the rest.

Good service with a good selection of wines and a sommelier on hand to give advice. Food is excellent with some great menu options for some modern French cuisine. With a good ambiance and nice décor, La Trompette is a great place to go for a special night out.

Loved this place. The most adorable waiters and waitresses, feel very well looked after. The food is fantastic, all perfectly cooked with an excellent combinations of flavors.
Lastly if for nothing else.. go for the truffles they send you away with.. divine!

result.name: Club Gascon
result.address: 57 West Smithfield, London EC1A 9DS, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: My other half loves French food, and I have to say that this is probably one of the best places we've ever been to! The menu is really inventive and cooked to an incredibly good standard. Obviously it's not cheap, but for a special occasion it is absolutely worth it! If you can go with the tasting menu I'd recommend it - that way you get to try the full spectrum of flavours!

Club Gascon is just exceptional ! Being french and arrival in london recently, I am pleased to enjoy true French cuisine ! If you want to pass a wonderful moment, go to this restaurant.
The + : a team at your disposal that does everything for you to have a good time. 
Merci Club Gascon !
Beautiful dinning experience. Manager and all staff were pleasant, the food was beautifully presented and superb. Couldn't have asked for anything more.

Deeply unimpressive, uninspired mediocrity. Food was prepared in a technically proficient manner, but not a single item truly impressed. Value for money was extremely poor. Service was curt, unhelpful, and snooty. Does not in any way deserve it's Michelin star. This was the second worst tasting menu I've ever experienced, and I've experienced quite a few. Each dish, even the better ones, had areas of significant weakness. Would not recommend.

For more than 11 years, chef-patron Pascal Aussignac has been building his reputation in The City, especially around Smithfield Market. His first venture was Club Gascon, which has since extended to the Cellar, the Comptoir Gascon, the recently opened Cerle in Chelsea and.....

result.name: The Camden Head
result.address: 100 Camden High Street, London NW1 0LU, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Don't get to Camden much these days since moving further east so I hadn't come across this place until recently. Maybe a bit busy for my liking but that's probably not their fault! There was comedy on upstairs when we visited but we'd just missed it, so maybe next time

This pub has everything going on. Storyteller's, guest DJs, Food, Comedy and much more.

Whilst the venue does say it is a Gastro Pub I differ in opinion, it is more a pub with good food, nothing gastro just good.

The pub is one o fCamden’s oldest pubs, established in 1787. Well worth a visit.
Good pub close to Camden tube station. It smells like you would expect from a pirate boat, but overall prices are ok and on the top floor a open mic night is hosted for some comedy or music.

This is the worst bar experience I've ever had in London. Went out for my good friend's celebratory night and not only was the service rude towards her, they ended up overcharging myself for two drinks and claiming that I ordered four (when my mate already paid for the two before). Discussing this with the bar staff and their "manager" was fruitless. They refused to check the register for the payments or do anything to rectify the situation. Highly disappointing, with severe lack of understanding or courtesy towards the customers. Will warn anyone I know against going there ever again.

The Camden Head is a whole lotta hype, though I have had many enjoyable nights with friends here. In the evenings at's crowded (as you'd expect for a bar on Camden High Street), you'll have to wait ages for a drink (and that's once you've reached the bar), and the prices are steep for what's on tap (but that's probably due to the location). Regardless, if you're after a late, boozy night in Camden with some drinks and dancing The Camden Head is probably your most affordable option.

result.name: Ye Olde Mitre
result.address: Ely Court, Ely Place, London EC1N 6SJ, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
They offer 360 degrees tour on their website. This is nice, especially when you have no idea how the place looks like. I visit Ye Olde Mitre, because of the award-winning beers and the tasty dishes.
The opening hours are normal, they close around 21:00 - 21:30, so it is possible to go there after work.

I wouldn't have known about this place if my friends hadn't brought me here for an ale. The atmosphere is great - very quaint, traditional and welcoming. They have quite the selection of beer form all over the world and the food is very delicious, what you'd find in a Fuller's pub. No surprises here, just good atmosphere, traditional interior and prompt service. The perfect place to grab a beer with friends.

After 30 years service in City of London Police I was searching for a suitable venue to celebrate my retirement. Although located just outside the City boundary I could not have made a better choice. There was no charge for reserving the upstairs room which was perfect for our needs. The staff were welcoming and friendly without being intrusive and everyone enjoyed the evening. Food is very simple - toasted sarnies, pork pies, scotch eggs, sausage rolls, nuts. The beer was very well kept and the choice good. It's a Fuller's pub but guest ales are always available and change every week. Prices are reasonable for London too.
As for the building, well go judge for yourselves. A genuine grade 2 listed Georgian gem on a site dating from the 16th century.

When it comes to old London pubs this one takes some beating. It dates back to the 1500's and is hidden away down a narrow alleyway of Hatton Garden. There's no loud music, no fruit machines, just the babble of good, and sometimes animated conversation. Just be warned though that it never opens at weekends and public holidays.
Loved it. Some newbies some business guys and best of all some really old salts hanging out drinking some pints.

result.name: The Drayton Court hotel
result.address: 2 The Avenue, London W13 8PH, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Hurray for the Drayton Court Hotel!! It is our local and my wife and I had our wedding reception here last week. The food for our 40 guests was fabulous. The service, perfect. Family and friends came from America, Scotland,Canada and Dorset and stayed with us at the hotel. They raved about the rooms and the atmosphere and the incredible staff. Our special day was made that much more memorable by choosing the Drayton!

Stayed there for a week and we loved it. The staff is fantastic - they really take care of you. The morning breakfasts were wonderful. We enjoyed just relaxing and having lazy mornings at breakfast there before hitting London for the day. The full bar downstairs is a true classic as is the hotel itself, lots of history. The beer garden in the back was delightful too. Really felt at home there.
Wouldn't call it a gastropub, but good food for a pub.

Surprisingly BIG! Fantastic decor, and the place itself is very nice to hangout in. Service is standard, what you would expect, and nothing more (a shame as they could really take off with extra zing to their customer service). A great place to hangout after a day's work, and because it's just right next to West Ealing Station (20 minutes from Paddington) it's a nice place to arrange meet-ups too!
A firm favourite with families due to its large garden. It can be a little noisy in the pub but if you can get outside in the garden, then it's great. The steep steps can be a bit tricky to navigate.

result.name: The Halkin by COMO
result.address: 5-6 Halkin Street, London SW1X 7DJ, United Kingdom

result.name: Wilton's Music Hall
result.address: 1 Graces Alley, London E1 8JB, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
My favorite place to grab a pint in London, and I often think about how old buildings like this would have toppled in a Californian earthquake a long while ago.

An old ale joint from the mid-1700s, it's now the world's oldest music hall (and I think they still do wacky shows like werewolf operas). Summer is a great time to hang out here since the sunshine is still golden right after work, and it's honestly nice to pop a squat outside Wilton's to drink in Graces Alley. 

Not that the tables inside aren't somehow perfectly rustic, and all the hipster paraphernalia that seems to come out of a box fits in well here. The stairs look like they'll collapse soon, and there are little goblets of flowers on the tables.

Beers are standard central-London prices, but they serve up some nice brews, especially from Kernel from just south of the river. Highly recommend the citra IPA for a good hoppy kick in the teeth as the sun goes down.

Random, but Wilton's has such nice-smelling soap in its bathrooms. That's all.

Beautiful venue! Great for a friends gathering or a date in the upstairs room. Also really enjoy sitting outside during the summer evenings. Being located in a very narrow, cobled street, the surrounding environment feels quite Continental and you will easily start chatting away with others outside. 
They have several events in their main hall including theatre plays, swing dancing nights and more so definitely worth following Wilton's on social for updates on what's going on.

Wilton Music hall is one of the most atmospheric venues in London. Its hidden away not far from the Tower of London but what feels like miles from the tourist trap. Arrive early and have a drink at the cosy Mahogany Bar (which is almost 300 years old), surrounded by the strange juxtoposition of neon signs and vintage gig posters, they do amazing seasonal specials like Pimms Cocktais and Winter Warmers. The venue itself is incredibly intimate, filled with fairy lights church pews, the perfect place to see a treasured band!
Core lm qod qo pp omar deep
Only made our first visit recently and loved it. Can't wait for the full restoration. Well done guys, looking forward to a return visit. It's Magic :-)!

result.name: Yauatcha
result.address: 15-17 Broadwick Street, London W1F 0DL, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
Having been to Hakkasan and Hkk couple of times, I was disappointed with the Yauatcha experience.
I expected the ambiance and service to be the same as these two excellent restaurant's in the same group. We arrived on time to be told there was a small wait, which was no problem as we were shown to the bar. After a short wait we were shown to our table which are very low without much leg room. We ordered the Signature Dim Sum Menu for 4. After the first course I noticed that the queue waiting for tables had grown and that the service had speeded up to a rush. They have quite small tables but now most of the courses very arriving making it uncomfortable to enjoy eating with a table brimming with plates. After the dessert plates very removed, a member of the waiting staff asked if everything was ok because they needed the table! Our intention was to finish our drinks and then leave but we were now a burden and once £345 had been extracted from my wallet they were happy to show us the door. Michelin Star service I don't think so. My advise is to pay a bit more and have the full experience at Hakkasan and Hkk.

Yautcha is a good place to relax over a cup of Asian tea and enjoy very high quality cakes. The staff are inexperienced generally and front of house a bit rude/lazy. Extremely overpriced but that's not a big problem if the staff were nice -- which they generally are not, having been here over half a dozen times.

We arrived at 6pm for an early dinner and I was initially impressed with the decor and ambience but this all changed pretty quickly.
We ordered our food and all throughout the meal there was a constant sense that we were deliberately being hurried so we would leave. When this was raised with the manager his response was that yes we were being rushed because they needed the table. I could maybe understand it if it were a budget restaurant but it's not.
It's a real shame because the food was pretty good but would have been a whole lot better if we'd been allowed to enjoy it.
Avoid...

Best dim sum in London; all the food is superb Recently discovered their macaroons, which are great. 
A favorite for sure!

One of the most impressive Dim Sum restaurants in this part of London. I've celebrated my last 2 birthdays here, and the fact that I came back after the first one speaks for itself. The staff is attentive and responsive to special requests, which is really cool. The prices are also reasonable for a restaurant of this calibre.
Definitely recommend it.

result.name: Scala
result.address: 275 Pentonville Road, King´s Cross, London N1 9NL, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Absolute rabbit warren of a nightclub/music venue, do not be surprised if you get totally lost. Beautiful old building though, lots of bars and toilets scattered throughout and a mad, varied programme. Open suitably late for last minute dancing after bars and pubs close, frequented by young music types.

I've only been to Scala on a night out twice. Both times I had a blast! There were a lot of rooms to choose from and is a building designed for exploring :P The main stage area had air condition which was great too. As with everything else in central London drinks were crazy expensive (£3 for a small bottle of coke!) and even the staff who served us empathised at how expensive it was lol. But don't let the price of drinks stop you from coming here for an awesome night, this is what pre-drinking is for!
Amazing huge old building with a curious distribution of the levels. There are many rooms, balconies and dancefloors. The staff is very friendly and prices are reasonably.

A great venue, over 4 levels which offers everything from a small intimate dancefloor on teh ground floor, huge main room on 1st, bar on the second and medium sized dancefloor on the top. Also do drinks deals occasionally which is unusual for a big london venue

I guess the first and foremost thing you need to know about this club is that the music played here is a rock and roll style. The music is crazy and the place seems like a maze, but it is so much fun even to be lost and talk to different people, while trying to get oriented and being boozed  If you are eager for a rock and roll escape or a rave night, this is the place to escape!

result.name: Langan's Brasserie
result.address: Stratton Street, London W1J 8LB, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
From iconic to chronic
A lot of people laud the old fashioned service but unfortunately that also reads as an old fashioned attitude to disability. Enjoyed a great meal with friends totally ruined by being told that wheelchair users had to use public toilet out on street (It was pouring down with rain) Hello 21st century please introduce yourself to Langans and please at least have the manners to offer an umbrella and an apology. Happy to take the £££s of me and my friend but completety ignorant of my embrassment and no mention made. Absolutely shameful. Does the DDA mean nothing?

Turned up on company day out - table of 10. Given wrong table, fight broke out next door table, terrible food, waiters rude and kept barging into us. When we did send some food back, hadn't turned up until 30 mins later when we raised the issue. No apology and having been a regular over the years, will never go back. Could have been the biggest off night they have ever had but I am not prepared to risk it.

The food here is very good. My family and I came here after our neighborhood hotel recommended this place our first day in London. The decor is very chic and elegant. My kids and wife felt under dressed as we saw many people in sports coats and we did not travel with our fanciest of duds. Still we did not look like we just climbed off an oil rig and were still dressed appropriate.
London is famous for it`s inferior cuisine, but this is a shining example of the new London with excellent choices. Each of our dishes were superior.
Regrettably, the experience was tarnished by the most inferior service imaginable. As we were not regulars, came with young teenagers, and did not order alcohol, we were treated like second class citizens. While other tables where lavished with multiple servers, even those with only two people, were waited on hand and foot, we were basically ignored after we placed our order. 
I felt like we were at a snoot-fest and we were the inbred cousins who crashed the party. 
We were shown a dessert menu, but this was merely a perfunctory effort as no one was really interested in taking our order. It`s a shame, because it probably would have been equally as delicious as the dinner and we most definitely would have ordered desserts. 
Frustrated by the quality of the service being a direct opposite of the quality of food, we got our check and left dissatisfied, despite eating what would be our finest dinner in London.

One of the few places I enjoy time and time again. Warm, professional service - they are excellent waiters who take pride in their work and they treat you well. Those who like restaurants which are all glitz over substance should avoid this place. It's down-to-earth and unpretentious, with an excellent menu of traditional fare, done very well. Buzzy and fun ambience and an eclectic clientele. Nicely spaced tables too - no sitting cheek-by-jowl by other people. A great night out.

Visted the restaurant last night, we were a table of 12, and we had mixed reviews firstly the waiter took are drinks orders randomly, so kept coming back with 2/3 drinks at a time? Regarding the Starters the ones who had the Souffle felt they were small portions, whereas the Goats cheese and red onion tart was too big! With regards the main courses, the most popular for flavour was the grilled Lobster, but again the portion was small, I had the Christmas Turkey dinner, it was unedible, the potatoes tasted like they were reheated, and the food was barely warm and where were the Sprouts? I could not eat it. The waiter said I should have complained, but to be perfectly honest, the services was such a shambles I lost my appetite, some of the side dishes, were still coming to the table after a couple of people had finished eating and if I had complained, my food would have arrived after everyone else had finished eating. It was such a shame as this was our annual Xmas dinner, there was no party atmosphere and overall we would give Langans a score of 4/10. The best part of the evening was Kay Presto!

result.name: Hilton London Paddington Hotel
result.address: 146 Praed Street, London W2 1EE, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
OVERPRICED. I'm not a big review writer but this was so bad I felt compelled to write something. 

I came here on business. In the morning at breakfast our waiter never brought us the coffee we wanted so my colleague and I went next door to Starbucks. We brought the coffee back into the Paddington Hilton and sat down to discuss the upcoming meeting. An employee told us it was against hotel policy to sit in the lobby and drink Starbucks so he said we either have to leave or throw away the coffee we just bought. 

Right now as I sit in my room, it is 12:20am and I can here the music from the reception room on the other side of the hotel. I have to be up for a 7:00am flight tomorrow and I won't be getting any sleep. I can hear the music so well I can even make out the songs. Two songs ago was Notorious BIG and the song now is Michael Jackson. I called reception to ask them to turn it down and they said they would turn down the music in 45 minutes. This is among the most over-expensive, awful hotel experiences I have had. Definitely the worst Hilton. Look anywhere else before using this hotel. 

Also, in my room with the fan on high and the temperature set as low as possible, I've had to sleep without any covers because it's so hot in here. It's the middle of December and very cold outside and yet this hotel has managed to make it uncomfortably warm. I'm so glad I'm leaving tomorrow.

Recently came here for afternoon tea with my mum. To say that I was disappointed would be an understatement. 

Starting off we arrived to find it would be served in what only you could describe as a canteen area. Then pronounced my name back to me incorrectly.

Before we were seated they asked if we would like our champagne at the beginning or end, we clearly stated the end but it was the first thing they brought to us. This was slowly followed by a tier of plates with a very small selection of cakes and sandwiches and eventually our pots of tea actually arrived.

I would definitely not got back, I've experienced much better than this and would have thought somewhere like the Hilton would have much better standards.

Stayed with my family for a long weekend. The breakfast was really good, with a good selection on offer. The rooms are very basic for a 4 star hotel and not overly impressive. No free wifi seemed a bit tight considering the rate. The location is fantastic though, but the hotel itself seemed run down in parts. Both mirrors in the line toilets were cracked and taped up and no toilet roll in cubicle. The carpet on the staircase was patchy and generally needs some updating. I would have expected a higher standard given the name, but OK for a weekend.

Good hotel in a great location.

We just spent 2 nights in the Queens Suite and to be honest it would be hard to fault it.

Rooms were of a good size for central London and staff were helpful and polite.

We had young kids and found the bus a much easier way of getting round town. The 23 bus drops you right outside the hotel.

Don't come here thinking you'll fit in a quiet hour on a phone meeting. The noisiest hotel lounges I have sat in for a long time. Kind of what you'd expect for a hotel attached to a railway station. The acoustics are horrible though. NOISY!

result.name: L'Escargot
result.address: 48 Greek Street, London W1D 4EF, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
Alors! I'm not a big fan of French food, so L'escargot was never on my list of places to dine at in London. For this, I owe this restaurant and its staff a humble apology. I dined here for a party and I found the service and food to be well above my expectation. 

I was unambitious with my food choices: lobster salad to start and rib-eye steak as a main. The lobster salad was the biggest surprise - the lobster was much higher quality than I normally expect in a mid-market London restaurant and the salad was very well balanced in terms of flavour. I don't think I've had a salad I've enjoyed that much in a long time. The steak was also better than I was expecting - cooked exactly to order and very tender. Additionally, the steak knife was razor sharp, which made eating the steak much more civilised than normal. Other people on the table were more ambitious. The eponymous snails were apparently very good, and the fish dish (bass, I think) was well received. The one element letting the food down was that it was all a little too salty for my taste. 

The wine was very good - I only drank the red but the white was apparently the better bottle. The service was warm and friendly right from the lady at front of house, though a few inexperienced (but still friendly) staff prevented them from scoring perfectly. 

I will definitely be going here again at some point to experience more of the menu. It's excellent value.

Absolutely loved L'escargot. I came here for lunch with clients and would highly recommend it. The food was beautiful and the service attentive and perfect. Highly recommend coming here. 
I used to come here often 2 years ago but nearly a year ago it seemed to lose it's charm. It's back.

It's lost it's service and quality. Avoid! We went one lunchtime. I use to go here a lot 10 years ago when it was a great restaurant but now it's terrible. Service was slow and poor. Quality of food was terrible. Very overpriced. Far better restaurants to go to in the area. Sadly once a great restaurant and now below average.

Very romantic atmosphere, the staff is extremely attentive and friendly. We took a 2 courses menu at very reasonable price. Onion soup and also duck with beets and roasted hazelnuts was delicious. Our outstanding experience in London

In our 15 years together, it's one of our favourite restaurants in London that we keep returning to for those special occasions. This visit was to celebrate our 10th anniversary which I mentioned in my booking in hopes of getting a 'special' table. It was such a nice surprise to not only get that but glasses of champagne on arrival and madelines with 'Bon anniversarie' written on the plate for dessert. Needless to say the service was brilliant, the food exquisite and atmosphere enjoyable. It may not be the 'new & trendy' kid on the block but sometime spending time with a trusty old friend is just what you need, like going home for a big friendly hug.

result.name: The Punchbowl
result.address: 41 Farm Street, London W1J 5RP, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: I went here for a family dinner last weekend. It has a lovely atmosphere. Really cosy, it's quite small inside but that adds to the experience. The food was quite reasonable between £12 and £20 for most main courses and all the food is very good quality. Service was excellent, I would recommend a visit.
Can't say I've been impressed with the wait staff.The food was the shining star of the night - everyone loved it and they literally did whatever we wanted. Very awesome experience to me :)

Great pub! Staff are really attentive considering how busy it can get during peak hours..Food is really great but can sometime come up a little cold due to the size of the locations... people also tend to plot up in corners and you struggle to get a seat if you arrive late in the day..

Nice pub. The crowd that gathers here consist of really friendly people and the staff are really sweet. They also service some really delicious sandwiches and nice ales, which are all considerably cheap.

I liked this pub. Clean, well managed, nice environment, not owned by one of the breweries. It's exactly what you'd expect a pub to be in Mayfair.

Oh, and it's owned by a movie director. Which is kind of neat, too. I saw him there once, for whatever it's worth!

result.name: The Roof Gardens
result.address: 99 Kensington High Street, London W8 5SA, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
Arrived here at around 11.30pm for a night out with 3 of my friends. We knew this would be an expensive night of drinks so chose to have a few glasses of champs at home before hand!
The doormen and staff were lovely, met a girl called Maria at the door who was very nice and sat us at a table with drinks for the rest of the night.
We all really enjoyed it, music and the atmosphere, leaving here around 3am..... Would definitely like to visit in the day to appreciate the surroundings and greenery!

Make sure that your overdraft is unlimited coz here you're gonna be needing it. (Unless you're filthy rich, or a trustfund kid or a lady who lunches) Despite the money thing the ambience here is beautiful, but don't take my word for it really it's one of those places to go and witness yourself and then you'll be able to say " I've been to the roof gardens"!!!
Overpriced! Really rude staff. The only reason it gets to stars as the drink itself was nice and the venue is really different. It's worth A visit but not as a regular place to go.
Great place. Excellent food. Interesting surroundings. Haven't seen a flamingo though.
A brilliant place for nice summer drink.

result.name: Barfly
result.address: 49 Chalk Farm Road, London NW1 8AN, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Amazing music is this club, located in the famous neighbourhood of camden. Is quite small but cozy. Bar at the ground floor and venue upstairs. For rock&roll fans!

A rocking little venue near Chalk Farm underground which has a nice atmosphere if you just want to come for a drink, then upstairs there's a dancefloor and stage which plays host to everything from hometown bands just getting started to big names who want to just play an intimate venue. I've seen a good few of my friends' bands' EP launches here and always had a great time.
Good music on both levels, with live music sometimes. Fun atmosphere with a good crowd of people. Reasonably priced entry and drinks. Overall a fun, inexpensive night out, I recommend it!

This ended up being my main haunt the first time I lived in London. The variety of different clubnights here combined with the fun and friendly vibe is absolutely second to none. The staff are usually cheerful and the bands are always well-selected. I've had some nights here where the DJs have pleasantly surprised me over and over again - I love those nights. :-)

For me, this is a venue I'd recommend to anyone wanting to get a flavour of the London music scene. It's an institution.
Good night ruined by an over-the-top bouncer and one rude woman behind the bar. Beer tastes disgusting and is served in plastic but great music.

result.name: The Dove
result.address: 19 Upper Mall, London W6 9TA, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: This is a hidden gem in Hammersmith area. Totally love it, the terrace in the back is wonderful and prices are ok. It doesn't matter if you're going for a beer or dinner, this is good for any event. Totally recommended, and compulsory stop if you're living in the West.
Great spot - pop on the balcony if the sun is up for a drink with a view or huddle inside for cosiness if it isn't - just watch your head as it is a very low ceiling affair! Lovely pub

Now that's what I call... Pub
If you're one of the few to achieve to get a seat at the rear balcony during a sunny day, you'll have a great day out. So simple

Cosy traditional pub. Staff very friendly and having been here a few times never experienced anything contrary to that. Food OK but could be better. The batter on our fish was soft and soggy, not crispy as it should be. Mullet starter was very tasty though and with some chips on the side, would have made a great main course by itself. Price average to high

This is one of the coolest and tiniest pubs, close to the river and I am so lucky to live close by and often to have great times in there, whether I am having a good dinner or just over a glass of wine or dinner am enjoying the company of my mates.

result.name: Four Seasons Hotel London at Park Lane
result.address: Hamilton Pl, Park Lane, London W1J 7DR, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Four Seasons’ roast duck is one of the best I’ve ever eaten. The ambiance is nothing special but clean. I have no complains about the service, staff was prompt and friendly.

Afternoon tea was a fantastic experience. The traditional English tea, together with the Italian tea was a delight. A belated Xmas present with "my girls", Emma. Beccy & Nikki thoroughly enjoyed by all. Thank you to all the staff who made it so special, will definitely be back next year.

The Four Seasons Park Lane has none of the traditional stuffiness one might expect of a hotel of this stature. It's fairly recent renovation (spa included) has updated the style to a modern 'oriental-chic'. Suffice it say, there is still more than a hearty dose of festal red on display. Which certainly goes a long way to maintain the lavish opulence of the place. And if the rouge of the interiors were a gentle reminder that Christmas was fast approaching, the giant fir flanking the grand entrance was a less subtle nod to everybody's favourite day. From the elegant, banister hugging, festive runners, to the roaring log fire, the Four Seasons did a superb job of readying its patrons for Christmas. I must admit, I was hard pressed to make it out to a meeting here with two lovely American bloggers. The cold, wet December evening and an early start the next day formed a compelling incentive to stay at home. But ten minutes in and happily swilling a delicious Côtes du Rhône, the looming prospect of work the next day had vanished from my thoughts. The service was exemplary, if only because it was barely discernable. 

Check out my other favourite places and photos on Triptease.

We had our office's Christmas party at this Four Season's. The theme was the Prohibition era, and thus you could see servers going around serving champagne in tea cups! The interiors were very well done for the party, and the food was really really good. Had steak and mushroom soup, and they were amongst the best I've had. Last year our party was at Mandarin Oriental, and this one at Four Seasons was a thousand times better than that.
Very good hotel

result.name: Dinner
result.address: Mandarin Oriental Hyde Park, 66 Knightsbridge, London SW1X 7LA, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
This was my second visit to Dinner. It is a good restaurant with attentive, friendly staff but some of the dishes are a bit hit or miss. 

If you stick to the well known ones (meat fruit, tipsy cake), then you are on a winner .. but if you stray (like I did as it was my second time), then the results can be disappointing. 

The octopus starter was brilliant and the cod was good but the dessert (brown bread ice-cream) was very poor so much so I only ate half of it .. which for the amount of money you pay is not good enough.
Great meal and professional services. The staffs are all friendly and approachable. The food was also superb. Definitely one of the best.

I'll keep this short. It's incredible, perfect food. Never before have I tried so many different dishes and not been able to think of a single way to better it. It's the best restaurant I have ever been to, and I go to far too many. I had really high expectations and it far exceeded them. Perfect.
This was an experiance of a life time. The staff were fantastic, the food was outstanding. Good sized portions too.
Life time experience, the food was outstanding,good staff ,I love it.

result.name: The Forum
result.address: 9-17 Highgate Rd, Kentish Town, London NW5 1JY, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: We used the venue to shoot a promo for our forthcoming app. From beginning to end the staff were super helpful and the whole experience was smooth and painless. For what we wanted the venue worked perfectly. Highly recommended.

I was in The Forum on Lacuna Coil concert on Nov 1 2014.
The show featured also Devilment and Motionless in White bands.
Despite musicians are not novice and did all the best for the show, I couldn't really enjoy the music because of terrible sound. Even known songs were quite difficult to recognise. What can I say about unknown songs? It was just loud noise and nothing else. Definitely there were improper speakers in use.
As a result: I won't be able to convince myself of attending this place again. And I'd not recommend this to anyone.
Went to see Blancmange and Heaven 17. Staff really friendly. Atmosphere fantastic. Sound was brilliant. Acoustics in venue are very very good. Definitely one of my favourite venues.

Went there for the second time last night and while it is a great space the sound quality is terrible. 
It has no clarity meaning it is near impossible to hear lyrics and the nuances of the music. Won't be going back.

Our trip to The Forum was for Camera Obscura and we had a fun, dancing time! Drinks are expensive (as they always are at these types of venues) but the stage is visible from the bar which is handy while you are waiting. The sound quality was pretty damn good and even though we were at the back getting our boogie on, we managed to score a decent view! Not a huge venue which made it feel a bit more intimate, which was nice. Leaving was not a hassle either as they open up all the doors and the tube station is very close by so there was no rush to escape - overall, we had a nice experience here.

result.name: 12 Bar Club
result.address: 26 Denmark Street, London WC2H 8NL, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Loved the atmosphere and decor on the walls - old album covers and posters. The whole place has a kind of vintage feel to it, especially with the arcade. Music is great, a fine way to discover new good acts. A perfect place for live music, a few drinks and laughs, overall to have some fun and put the worries of the daily grind behind.

I love this place - it has everything for a great night out: live music, which still allows for a conversation, decently priced drinks, and lovely decor with old album covers and original artwork. The arcade with the pinball and ms pacman was a very pleasant surprise.
Great venue, nice people, well priced. This place is great for live music and good atmosphere with staff that know their subject matter - music. Its totally worth a visit.
Small bar.. it is a normal place. I like the drinks, but the atmosphere should be improved. This is my opinion, of course. I can't hide that some of the drinks are the tastier that I have tried.

I'll admit I judged this place before I walked through the door, but it is the very definition of a hidden gem. The club is covered in old album covers, music posters and drinks advertising that makes it feel like a true music-lovers venue. Staff were polite and drinks are pretty cheap considering the location. The back room has room to sit and offers up retro gaming classics - pinball and Mrs. Pacman! There was a live band playing that provided atmosphere, but you could still easily hold a conversation without shouting. Definitely worth a visit.

result.name: G-A-Y Late
result.address: 5 Goslett Yard, London WC2H 0EA, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: A place that refuses entrance to nice good looking people just because they think 7 is a big group doesn t even worth waisting my time doing a review
did not have a lot of fun cauz I hate commercial music ^^ but good club anyway
Great for a dance to pop music and cheap drinks! A fun place for everyone. Make sure to look after your bags in there though!
The best club in London - cheap drinks, free entry for members, just a magical place. I attend at least twice a week.

The place and the music was good but the service..I had to wait ages for a drink and please don't go to the blond barman! He didn't understand nothing about what I was asking and he argued with me cus he understood a different drink and he didn't served me cus he though that he was right!

result.name: Millennium Bailey's Hotel
result.address: 140 Gloucester Road, London SW7 4QH, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: A great hotel, very nice and friendly Personal.Have a club twin room, I set up really huge and absolutely clean, beautiful British as shown on the Picture.Room large single beds with a little too soft Mattress. Breakfast British and Continental, in a big bright Room.Bar with comfortable furniture for guests to let.Very end the day nice and pleasant hotel. Tube directly at the Door.Big Thanks for the pleasant stay.

It started of with the check in. I asked if they had internet and Antonio replied that its 10 pounds oer day (!) When i said i thought that was rediculous, he replied that he has a friend working at another hotel where its even more. Basically saying deal with it. Youre better of getting a internet sim on the high streets.

The second issue was in the room. You could clearly see the made went through it quickly. Thats a problem in current day hotels as they have to manage to clean a lot in little time. The toilet seat was spotted and so was the sink. Not a nice idea to go to the toilet. Also everything from the hallways to the rooms smell after chloride. Again not nice. In my room upon enteri i found the heating turned on its highest and on the warmest setting. Again, not what youre hoping for after a days hard work. The room i stayed in was 596. I guess normalky it would be a nice room if clean.

With breakfast asking for a cappuccino is to much. It will cost me an additional 4.35 pound (!) and the breakfast is 13.50 pounds. Price for breakfast is ok, but for my croissant and scrambled egg one might expect a bit more service translated in a cappucino. But 4.35 is an absolute rip off! The waiter smiled and seriously asked if i wanted one. Uhm no, ill get a proper one from Costa thank you.

The TV System is very buggy, and every channel keeps lagging or just freezes up.

Everyone is trained to get more money and up sell, service is clearly second. And thats what is wrong with this hotels management. I would strongly unadvice this hotel to any friend or family for the moment being.

Ps what is really nice is that they have a kids congierge. Albeit i dont have any myself, I do like that idea / service.

Stayed July, 2014, business trip

Super awesome location - few seconds away from the tube station (right across the street), several grocery stores and restaurants within the block. Stayed there for a week on Dec 2013. The customer service was awesome, got a free upgrade to a suite (one king size bed and a sofa bed) when they knew there were three of us (originally we booked a room with two twin beds). There was free wifi in the lobby. I'd definitely go there again if visiting London.
Same wonderful Indian food at this Bombay Brasserie as at the other.

Food is way overpriced. And seriously.....charging for room internet service? 20pounds/day? I can't even use the term nickled and dimed as everything seemed to be outrageously-punch you in the face- expensive as an add on. What I can get for free at a Holiday Inn....A HOLIDAY INN....was not complimentary here. I would never stay here again. Yes, it's convenient, but so is the Holiday Inn and the Crowne. Next time, I'll walk a block to the tube. Although...helpful staff.

result.name: Tom's Kitchen
result.address: 27 Cale Street, London SW3 3QP, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
Visited Tom's Kitchen on 12/08 for a fantastic breakfast! I had friends in town from Australia and Canada and they loved the breakfast dishes and coffee.

My new favourite breakfast restaurant worth every penny.

I discovered Tom's Kitchen while searching for brunch destinations in London and, after reading many positive reviews, I decided to try it myself.
I didn't know who Tom Aikens was, so I wasn't after the celebrity chef, though I did become suspicious when I discovered how hard it was to find a table at the Chelsea branch. Advance booking is necessary!
Tom's kitchen is located in a beautiful townhouse, off King's Road and within walking distance from South Kensington station. It's bright and sunny; elegantly decorated without being too posh. The clientele is young couples or families with little kids.
The food is very good: I recommend the Egg Royale, poached eggs served on English muffins with smoked salmon and hollandaise sauce, and the French Toast.

Delicious breakfasts and lots and lots of place to sit - perfect combination. These days you need to book a table, though. Blueberry pancakes (with the berries baked in), French toast and omelettes are brilliant. Milkshakes are decadent. Service is generally pretty good. Lovely on a sunny day (and a dull day too, not to worry).

Excellent omelet for brunch we had here. The sweet stuff not near as good but the eggs worth a trip.

Says something in their menu about having some special organic shmorganic egg source.
Great and simple food. Good service.

result.name: The Ship Tavern
result.address: 12 Gate Street, Holborn, London WC2A 3HP, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
We had to try three other "pubs," all horribly yuppified, before finding The Ship.

Love it! Feelslike home.
A really lovely hidden pub stowed just out of the way of busy streets. Well kept real ales, friendly service and good food. A charming atmosphere and really nice interiors.
A proper pub with good atmosphere. I had a pint of 1549 which was spot on.

Great pub and restaurant; certainly worth a visit. Disappointing change in menu recently however - what used to be an enormous plate with pork belly that I'd happily recommend to anyone is now a plate of black pudding & greens with 3 small slices of pork on top. Please revert to previous recipe!!!

An amazing little pub situated slap bang in the middle of Holborn. Wonderful food and lovely service, this place provides a welcome oasis away from the hectic central london wild life. Serving the full array of pub foods and decorated in a classic pub style with wooden panelling. Always a nice place to pop for meal and a good drink.

result.name: King's Head Theatre
result.address: 115 Upper Street, Islington, London N1 1QN, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: My friend discovered a cigarette butt in his pint and remonstrated with the shift manager who accused him of attempting a scam. The shift manager eventually provided an additional half to replace the spoiled beer but accused him of being "a not nice person", threatened to call the police(!) and used the threat of a bouncer to force us to leave. Our behaviour in no way merited this kind of response and the shift manager displayed bad faith and shocking lack of regard for their customers. I would not recommend this pub until the management changes.

It's a little worn at the edges, is crazily crowded, and doesn't have the most inspiring of drinks, but what character this place has - how many pubs do you go to that also put on opera performances?

The theatre attached to the back of this pub might have seen better days, but they pack in some wonderfully eclectic performances and events that make this place a really interesting venue. Themed opera nights, plays, comedy, and more.

If you've tickets for an evening performance, get there early, as the bar is fairly narrow and gets crowded very quickly, especially when the queue for the night's performance starts to build.
That used to be my favourite spot with Blues/Jazz music and now it's just an ordinary pub, with a nice interior but no soul and newly built kitchen. It's a pity to have witnessed that.

Nice pub with some great live bands! Unfortunately a relatively young man who claimed to own the place (not sure if this were true) has driven us away when he was seen making fun of a homeless person who was walking by.... won't rush going back.
Great beer. Great music. Great Theatre. I am so lucky to have lived so close to this wonderful pub.

result.name: De Hems Dutch Cafe Bar
result.address: 11 Macclesfield Street, London W1D 5BW, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
Oh my goodness, this place serves my favourite Belgian beer, Fruli!!!! I have been working around this area for 4 years now.....and never walked into this pub.

Leffe, another good Belgian beer, is also there! Woo!!

So I asked a few fellow lawyers and lawyers in training to attend this amazing place and we loved it. There were quite some space to stand around, the barmaid was quite attentive (I am so sorry that our group took a while to decide what we were ordering) and she remained patient. The other patrons are all well dressed and noone was drunk, this is a good sign.

Sometimes you could smell tantalising food being delivered to patrons, the smell of jacket potatoes were so good. Next time I will definitely order food here if I had no other plans.

No wonder, that time after doing some filming as an extra in China Town, I saw Jason Statham walk straight into this pub. That's a thumbs up from celebrity yo!
I love De Hems. It's pricey, but you get what you pay for. Great beer, lovely food and friendly service. An anathema in China Town.
Amazing beers and great staff who were very happy to help me through their extensive beer menu. I recommend the rochefort10

I'm no expert in Dutch bars (or beers) so tend to go with the flow on these matters. De Hems didn't disappoint. The alcohol percentage was higher than normal but the flavour wasn't compromised. And the different shaped glasses that accompany the beers are interesting. It has a large selection of drinks, nice decor and a friendly atmosphere. It's worth a visit if you fancy something different.
Nice pub in central London. Usually very busy and not the most conformable, but their wide range of beers makes up for this.

result.name: London Stone
result.address: 109 Cannon Street, London EC4N 5AD, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Gothic themed bar, fake bookcases lead to the toilets. They serve the 7 Deadly Sins cocktails which are excellent and the food is pretty decent and not overpriced. For a city centre bar it's never too busy either. Since Ben Crouches left us, this is the best gothic (themed) pub in London

Meh. It's a pub. Tries to be gothic but doesn't quite succeed. Just an average pub.

It also doesn't have air-con, though that probably isn't a problem most of the time.
Underwhelming

result.name: Barcode
result.address: Arch 69, Albert Embankment, London SE1 7TP, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Club full of drug addicts. Guys standing in long queues to the restroom to get high there. Drug dealers shamelessly offer you drugs next to the bar counter.

Friendly gay bar. Great funktion 1 sound system in the back room, be aware at weekends usually hosts cruisy-type parties however if you're looking for a late night venue where you don't have to re-mortgage your house a good place to go, and a 1 minute sprint to the train station if you have to run for a train!

Music has improved so much that it's becoming one of my favourite clubs. Two rooms of great music and great people 
Dark room is always busy but get's too hot.
Great Team good Musik nice People and super Dj's.I Love it and i miss

Great friendly place to hang out with friends to start the night and have a drink before going to an afterhours club in the early hours of the morning. Great music and sound system in the back dance room and fantastic disco ball lighting

result.name: The Argyll Arms
result.address: 18 Argyll Street, London W1F 7TP, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: In an area spoiled for choice for decent pubs there's no need to put up with this this one. Good luck getting served. The extra 2 minute walk to any of the vastly better pubs around Carnaby St is well worth the effort.
Very expensive. A glass of wine was £5 and a J20 (apple and mango) £2.50. Decor very dowdy.
Expensive diet pepsi. Cheaper to buy a lager!

Some bar staff are outgoing which makes for a fun experience. One of the bartenders offered a few beer tastes to allow for selection of a full pint. Dinner upstairs was tasty enough. I was a bit concerned going in knowing it was a chain pub, but overall the experience was positive. I would return.

This place has the looks and the tasteful details making the overall classic atmosphere that I definitely look up to when visiting a pub. It's always really busy but the friendly staff and the quality food makes up for that. I would recommend trying the Line-caught cod fillet with skin-on chips although my personal favourite is Ginger-beer glazed pork belly. The selection of ales is picked to match the season and the meal you are having.

result.name: Galvin at Windows
result.address: 22 Park Lane, London W1K 1BE, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Great food, couldn't fault the venison main and milk chocolate soufflé for dessert! Very highly recommended. Will definitely be going back.

Galvin at Windows is always a favourite of mine. My partner and I manage to go about 3 times a year for special occasions or just to treat ourselves. 
Service and food is always impeccable, and the staff always remember us and greet us with a very warm welcome. 
We very much look forward to our next visit. 
I'll might hint at my fiancée to take me for my birthday in April.

What an elegant and sophisticated place! We walked in and were greeted by all the staff, who continued to attend to us until the moment we left. There was clearly a lot of thought that had gone into optimising on a customers experience, which myself and my date really appreciated. We sat down and were given postcards of the view from the restaurant, which we were told could be written and sent to anywhere in the world. My date was quick to take advantage of this, sending the postcard to New York!
The food itself was also beautifully presented and a real gastronomic delight. Special mention in particular to my main - a lamb reforme with a pomme mousseline (basically the smoothest and richest mash you will ever have), with a slice of truffle and a rich sauce poured over at your table. Ermagaad. Also to my dessert! A light and crisp rose meringue, on top of which a light coating of vanilla studded cream, capped with a mushroom-head of violet meringue. So fragrant and floral, it was like eating a bouquet. A pleasant surprise of truffles and raspberry jellies (you would have thought to end the meal), and a candy-jar of green apple and passionfruit marshmallows! A decadent night from which we left, glowing.

Stunning views of London from the 28th floor of the Hilton, with an excellent menu to match, Galvin at Windows is the place to go if you want a bit of the wow experience without being too over the top. Head chef Joo Won's kitchen turns out consistently good food, and the steamed cod is a must-try. 

With a number of offers available on Open Table, a meal there isn't too expensive either. Opted for the £29 for three courses and two glasses of wine, which was great value for money.

Serving french cuisine on the 28th floor of the Hilton on Park Lane, the michelin starred restaurant boasts quite the view over Mayfair, not short of iconic sights such as The Shard and Hyde Park. What more, to ensure a dining experience to be remembered, our table of 8 were given 3 postcards of the panorama view which they would even help you mail off to anywhere in the world. The staff were most attentive and paid immaculate attention to detail. The room is contemporary and elegant but nothing outstanding. The portions were just nice and the food was spectacular in the sense that it tasted like the finest quality but view aside, I found it a bit forgettable.

result.name: Milk & Honey
result.address: 61 Poland Street, London W1F 7NU, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Visited on a member's night: GREAT cocktails — probably one of the few places I've been in London that makes an excellent Long Island — and good food to boot. Great staff, excellent ambiance (speakeasy, mood lighting) with a nice little grotto that's perfect for a date or night out with friends.

A "member's only" bar in Soho. A very welcome classy, quiet and intimate space to escape the madness and crowde streets of the bar scene nearby. Was invited by my friend and we checked out the roof area on a sunny London afternoon. The bartenders here are world-class, friendly and make incredible drinks. I had the Brigadoon (Scotch, apricot, lemon, orgeat) and Boulevardier (Bourbon, Campari, Italian vermouth). 

There's several floors with different themes and ambiance's as well, from the open, light roof area to the darker and moodier downstairs booths, and fireplace room with velvet couches/

I had read that Milk & Honey was voted in the top 5 bars in london (perhaps in time out?) so im sad to say i was left underwhelmed. We opted for 2 rum based drinks and once my eyes had adjusted - its all candle light (Watch your shins on the stools on your way in!) they looked pretty much identical and taste about the same too. We were offered water and the service was prompt but for the £20 bill I failed to see what the fuss was about. Perhaps if you could see the bartender/mixologist doing his thing it may be a little more exciting.

I’ve been here only once with a friend of mine who’s a member of the club. I really enjoyed the privacy, the good music and the classic cocktails. I’m not a pretentious person and places like that isn’t a priority for me but I really liked this one. Next month I am going to NY for a while and I think I should visit the original Milk & Honey. Can’t wait!

Members bar, after 11pm. Still relatively hidden location on Poland Street, despite being around for over 10 years now. 

The drinks are really the reason to come, and they are still up there with the best in the world. Also, the extremely knowledgeable and likeable staff makes every visit a memorable one. 

The decor hasn't changed much in the last decade but I believe they are looking a gradual refurb in 2014.

result.name: The Anchor
result.address: 34 Park Street, Southwark, London SE1 9EF, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: I have visited this pub for the first time. My friends invited me there, last week. Great location, nice beer and friendly staff. I ordered beef burger - definitely the best one I've ever tasted. We spent amazing time. Next meeting will definitely be at the same place.

The place was very nice. Also, like in most places I've visited in London, the staff was very pleasant. However, it was kind of expensive for what we got, i.e. standard beer and not so good fish and chip. Hence, I felt it was a bit of a tourist trap...

This pub does the best Mulled Wine I have EVER tasted!

15 out of 10!

A very touristy pub, which I normally try and stay away from, but I actually like this place. Great location by the river, lovely outdoor area and great tasting ale.

Well priced beer and even the food isn't too bad.

horrible pub not friendly, drinks watered down ,workers were rude.
WOULD NOT GO AGAIN 💩 hole

result.name: Fitzroy Tavern
result.address: 16a Charlotte Street, London W1T 2LY, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Love this place. Go there for a pint of the organic lager and wheat beer! As a northerner (leeds/Middlesbrough) I was brought up on sam smiths in my youth, however london sam smiths pubs dont quite have the 'charm' of northern versions ( ie fearing for ones life). This is one of about 24ish smiths pubs in a square mile so plenty to choose from.... if you like sam smiths that is! The fitzroy has a lot of history as well apparently.... and its cheap.
Nice little pub, very traditional decor, and amazing (for London) prices. All the beers are Sam Smith's, but if you like that, like I do, it's great. Not too crowded either, most nights.

The gloomy, sank atmosphere, middling beer choices, and surly staff are not why I have given this pub a whopping 4 star rating. No, it is for the history of the place that I have been so generous.

Sitting here nursing a pint, you may be sitting in the very place Dylan Thomas, George Orwell, or members of the Bloomsbury Group sat and locked intellectual horns. Or the place that Steven Moffat belched out his latest Doctor Who nonsense, as it was once the home of regular Who fan meetups in the 1990s and 2000s.

It's not a bad place for a quick drink and a sit down - prices are surprisingly low for the location - and has nice outdoor seating if the weather is good. Go for the history rather than the service, and you're onto a winner.
Great Steak & Old Brewery Bitter Pie and Fish & Chips............and they brew their own beer!

What I would call a typical English pub. The food, decor and service are not the important aspects of the experience. It's meant to be dark, and the staff a little grumpy, but the beer (Sam Smith's) cannot be beaten, nor can the prices. Typical Yorkshire prices (rare for London) are the best.

result.name: The Magic Circle
result.address: 12 Stephenson Way, London NW1 2HD, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
WOWWOWWOW! I came here for the Magic Circle christmas show, a wonderful christmas present and it was one of the best outings of my life!
I've had a soft-spot for magic for years and have made no secret of mentioning this to people, one person got the hint and I am so glad they did.
Firstly, the building. It's in a rather strange place to be honest, a spooky backstreet that would fit-in on the set of a murder mystery/Sherlock. That door is there and promises much....
Inside you are greated immediately with a wonderful spiral staircase that, with the thanks of various mirrors, seems to go on forever somehow....
You'll find a museum in the basement which, unless you're really into magic history, may leave you cold (there is a Sooty in there though, he's a member)!
There is also a bar area and kind of reception room with a statue of the founder, good for functions one would imagine.
During the christmas show all these areas were littered with magicians doing close-up tricks and it was amazing.
Finally, we have the theatre itself, it's small, of course, but complete. It's a proper fine theatre and of course nice and intimate, as magic should be.
I'm so glad to have gone and really hope to return. I can't wait...

I went to see a Variety show at the Magic circle and it was the most awful experience that I have ever had the misfortune to pay for. They did not have enough acts that were good enough to be called variety. 
They padded the show out with a woman who played the piano, she was mediocre at best, an elderly couple who played jazz, and an old man who sang but quite frankly he should have retired years ago as he was very bad.
There was also a juggler who did not have a very good act.
The saving graces were a Magician who was very good and a ventriloquist who was amazing and the audience laughed until we cried.
I am a member of the magic circle and i am annoyed that you a revealing the secret HQ
Here for a conference followed by magic show and ask in all have to say the experience was great.
It's an awesome place of real magic.

result.name: The Troubadour Cafe
result.address: 265 Old Brompton Road, London SW5 9JA, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Yesterday I went for the first time in this coffee. Me and my old friend went there to get a cup of espresso. It was the perfect place with fine atmosphere. We enjoyed with a fancy coffee and delicious food! The staff is polite. I will come back again :)
Nice enough food, good service, cute ambiance and a sweet ass little live music venue downstairs with a nice bar. Been many times, never been let down

This is a very popular place and that's the main reason why it gets busy even on Monday night, when most bars or pubs would kill for some tables. The staff is attentive and you can be sure, they'd do their best to make your stay as enjoyable as possible.
Tasty sandwiches, nice cocktails and reasonable prices. What more could you ask for?
Loved it! Relaxed, friendly and interesting. Intimate spaces and fab vibe!

Went to see some live music in July 2014, and whilst the its an ok venue, some of the staff are a bit pretentious and up themsleves. Had a few beers, which was reasonable at about £3.50 a bottle, but then ordered a small bottle of water, and took a moment to realise the place was a joke when I got charged the same as the beer!!!

result.name: The Hippodrome Casino London
result.address: Cranbourn Street, Leicester Square, London WC2H 7JH, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Vile and touristy venue supplemented by possibly the most aggressive security door staff in London who regularly humiliate / harass people with a strip search just for the fun of a power trip,watch out in particular for Philip Stephenson - a doorman with a gigantic chip on his shoulder who subjected me a session of abuse under bogus pretences.I pray for the day Simon Thomas the CEO of Hippodrome Casino gets a taste of this particularly toxic style of 'security'!

A little slice of Las Vegas plunked into the middle of Leicester Square!

Open late for drinks, and we were treated to a sequence of dancing ladies in skimpy outfits before we filed into their cabaret space. Great show and it has a sort of lumpy scrappy charm.

So after the ladies of Team Canada (woop woop!) won gold in the jaw-clenching Sochi 2014 hockey game, I officially jumped on the bandwagon and was hanging on by a finger - I needed to catch the men's final gold hockey match! And what better place to do it than the Hippodrome Casino? While the Maple Leaf was the first venue of choice, the Canadian Meetup Group made arrangements for some loud and rowdy Canadians to watch the game in the first floor bar area. 

Never have I felt so classy wearing my red CANADA shirt, and jumper, while waving a massive flag and donning a maple leaf hat. There were extra chairs and tables brought out to the main bar area, a very posh lounge was set up with comfy couches and extra TV's, and they even opened up the cabaret theater to show the game on their massive screen! 

The amazing thing is that, amongst all the rowdy crowd who were jumping around, spilling beer everywhere, we received nothing but friendly top-notch service. A few things to note that I was impressed with: 

- 24-hour bar menu with decent price / quality food. £5 for 10 wings, £7.50 for burger & chips. Not sure where else you'd go for something like this around Leicester Square!
- The room was packed, people sitting in booths were annoyed that people standing around were blocking their view (but hey, where else were they to stand??). But the workers decided to drag out ALL their chairs, making sure everyone had a comfy seat, and no one's view was blocked. Ace.
- Our food order took an extremely long time - understandable that the kitchen was backed up with the few hundred Canadians that showed up! After checking with the waiter to make sure our order was at least in the system (and not lost), our order finally came out, along with a massive pitcher of complimentary beer. I wasn't even upset to begin with, I wasn't even expecting anything for free. But they went above and beyond to make sure we were happy. Funny enough, when the pitcher of beer was set down, Canada scored :) 

While this isn't a review on the actual gambling facilities, I think this is a great spot to catch the game with your buddies. Decent food for decent prices, posh facilities with friendly service. Felt pretty Canadian to me :) 

BTW, Team Canada won gold 3-0. GO CANADIA!
We had the night of our lives! Fantastic food and legendary entertainment. Definitely recommend a night out here! Cherry-Ann Ballantyne, Oxford

One of the worst experiences of my life. It's funny how they let American's in who they like on British Television. They wouldn't let me go in after I waited their '30 minutes' policy and are very rude and don't give a shit about any outsiders. If you are trying to gamble, make your way to Las Vegas. If you are in London, save your gambling money for a better time. You are bound to have a much better time with more respectable people and in an environment that perpetuates respectability. Every Casino near Hippodrome fails and ends up being a rip off.

result.name: Sopwell House
result.address: Cottonmill Lane, St Albans AL1 2HQ, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: It is odd to read of other peoples less than gratifying descriptions of their experiences here. My partner and I stayed here recently. In our opinion it is an absolutely lovely place to relax and enjoy superb food, great service (all the staff are extremely polite, but not overbearingly so), and take advantage of a luxury spa. Breakfast and dinner (in the Brasserie) were wonderful. Lots of choice, and absolutely everything we had was cooked and presented to perfection. Top marks! The gardens are nice, the patio a real sun spot, and everywhere is clean and tidy. If you look hard, and take your eyes off of the job of sunbathing or drinking a nice cocktail, you'll notice the staff are always beavering away as discretely as possible. For example, when you find a table to sit at outside, it is not pre-filled with the previous occupants left-overs. The gardens were maintained daily. There's no litter anywhere. Flowers and nice décor as far as the eye can see - indoors and outdoors. Our room was to a high standard. Very comfortable bed, full use of Sky TV, shower/bathroom lovely. Can't see how or why anyone would complain, but like I said at the beginning, we all have different experiences. Just pleased to say, ours was a brilliant one! We got a great deal pre-booked before we arrived, saving quite a bit off from the price if booked directly through the hotel's own web site. All in all, this is a really enjoyable place to stay for 2/3 days and we highly recommended it.

Very comfortable and nice hotel. I suggest it to everybody.
The only thing that should be fixed is the elevator's noise. 

Start-stop noise of the elevator is too high while staying in the room.
Enjoyed my time at Sopwell. The spa was wonderful
This is one of the popular venues for a wedding in Hertfordshire. My steel drum band has covered a lovely wedding reception there and it is evident that they are experienced in providing the service.

We stayed at Sopwell house for Valentines Day and I must say, the entire experience from start to finish was shocking.

We were overcharged on 3 bills including our final bill where were charged double the price of our stay.

I am now waiting for a refund to go back into my account for £374.00 which is totally unacceptable.

The room we had was of a good standard and the evening meal was also a mess from start to finish with them getting our starters wrong and having to wait for new starters to come out and the for them to try and charge us on our bill for stuff we didn't have.

Our overall experience has been extremely disappointing and I highly recommend you check every receipt and bill before payment

result.name: Clapham Tandoori
result.address: 10 Clapham Common South Side, London SW4 7AA, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: I went with my girlfriend for supper on the basis that it has been well reviewed. The chicken tikka masala was unlike any decent version I had ever eaten. The chicken itself was meant to have been cooked in a tandoor prior to being added to the sauce - it clearly had not as it did not have any of the delicious smokey, charred flavour you supposedly pay extra for. The sauce it came in was literally inedible-it was artificially red and tasted of nothing but sugary, grainy coconut. The sweetness was cloying. I was particularly surprised by the lack of any spice as I had asked for it to be spicier than usual as often chicken tikka masalas can be on the too mild side. My girlfriend ordered a completely different main course but to our horror it came with the same horrible sauce. Neither of us ate any of it. We informed the staff, who where very apologetic and removed the items from our bill. They where also generous enough to offer us another chicken tikka masala to take home - lucky us! Needless to say we declined the offer and left swiftly. If you want a proper curry head down the road to Tooting

FOOD: The food was of great quality. Really authentic. I braved the Phall with garlic naan, pilau rice, onion bargees and some potato dish. Everything was great. 

SERVICE: Brilliant. Really friendly and attentive yet still giving us plenty of space. Really enjoyed the atmosphere too. 

VALUE: Again, brilliant. I had the Wednesday deal for like £11, 4 things, it was amazing! 

Thanks.
Good Indian restaurant, with absolutely lovely staff at very reasonable prices. I love the free popadoms :) We mostly get delivery, but their restaurant experience is great too!

I had gone here with my sister to meet my mum for somewhere to eat and as we all love Indian food, my mum was advised to go here for lunch. Although the service was good and the environment was alright I disliked the food. It reminded me of something that was heated in a microwave then placed in a nice dish and served to me. The meat was touch and fatty. I wouldn't say I would never go back but I think I would go back there to make my last judgement as there might be a different chef. The service was excellent and the music was nice

Ordered here tonight after reading the glowing reviews.. Our starter was nice, but our mains were very bland. I could not taste any spice or seasoning in it. We actually ended up renaming the 'tarka dahl' to 'tarka dull'. The food is presented quite well and has all the gimics, they give you a lollipop with your order, but unfortunately the gimics are the most flavoursome bit. I would have rated it 'ok' but after spending £50 on two of us to have a curry take-out, I actually 'disliked' my experience.

If you aren't a fan of curry that's spicy or full of flavour then you will probably like it there.

P.S a warning to you all, i ordered a 'bottle of diet coke' priced at £2 expecting a large plastic bottle, but do not be mistaken.. this is a glass bottle, so definitely not enough for two people.

result.name: Nags Head
result.address: 10 James Street, London WC2E 8BT, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Medium sized Victorian gin palace. Haunt of tourists, locals, football fans and emergency service workers de-stressing. All human life is here. Good quality bar food and service with a smile. Beware the cost of a round though, London west end prices.
Great boozer. Helped get my stag night going. Thanks for putting up with me and my arsehole mates back in 2013!

Covent Garden tube station is a convient place to meet up with friends.

If they happen to be running late, this is a great spot to have a cheeky pint.

The decor is very much "Old Man's Pub", but with that decor goes good service. I'm (for better or worse) now recognised by some of the staff but even before that the service was good.

It dos get *very* busy on Thu / Fri / Sat nights, so a table will be hard to find, otherwise it is quite pleasant to sup a beer whilst your friends arrive.
Not a good pub. Staff do not speak good English so if your drink is wrong....tuff!

Good London pub that can get very packed with tourists due to location. I must be lucky with this pub as I often find it half empty with plenty of empty tables - a situation that doesn't last long as a rule. Beers are well kept - McMullen's AK and Cask Ale on my most recent visit, albeit expensive. I've never eaten here - I don't even know if they do food! Above average, especially considering it's in such a touristy area.

result.name: The Windsor Castle
result.address: 114 Campden Hill Road, London W8 7AR, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
I came here for a few drinks with a group of friends on a Wednesday night to celebrate one of our friend's birthday, and we had a reserved table in the garden area. The place was quite busy for a week-day.
The Garden was very pretty and cozy, but we did not realise that it was a smoking area. People at the table next to us were smoking non-stop, and for us non-smokers it was quite annoying to have their smoke blowing in our direction pretty much all evening. After spending an evening outdoors, i came home stinking of smoke.
The drinks were very expensive. I paid £19.10 for 2 draft beers, pims & a bowl of chips!
I liked the set up indoors and dark-wood interior. There are a few private sections inside for drinking and dinning. The selection of drinks was not huge, but enough to satisfy all tastes.
Unfortunately there are no bike-racks near the pub :(

A quirky, old, interesting pub with eye watering beer prices.
If you do not mind paying almost £6 a pint then go there.
Alternatively, turn the corner and walk 150m to the Churchill Arms where you will find a much better pub, with much better beer prices and bags more atmosphere.

I know where I will be going next time..

Love this pub for it's beer garden. The perfect way to spend a summers evening in London with friends and as the British summer night temperatures drop you can still stay outside as the heaters go on!! Only thing is, it's a little pricey -- Kensington prices apply (which is why I rated 4 stars not 5). 
Still, a very nice pub in London with very nice food and OH was impressed with the selection of beer on offer.

Terrible pub with serious staff training needs. This could be a lovely place with a beautiful garden area, lots of indoor seating and a pretty good location, but it fails to meet the mark. My first attempt to go to the bar in the garden area I was told to go inside because they needed to stock up - not sure why the staff roaming around couldn't do that. So I went inside only to wait about 10 mins in the stifling heat for the very slow staff to serve the people before me. Then on my second attempt to go to the bar there wasn't a queue, but someone before me and a girl behind the bar fully aware of our presence but far too busy stocking a cigarette machine. When I was finally served I was given a pint that wasn't even filled to a pint that cost £5.35! I will not being returning and I would recommend others avoid this place.
Quirky interior with internal "gates" between rooms. Seating largely on settles, but comfortable. Good range of beers served london style. Ask for a top up at London prices.

result.name: The Salisbury Hotel
result.address: 1 Grand Parade, Green Lanes, London N4 1JX, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Me and my friend return often to this pub whether we are looking to have a small dinner just the three of us on a weekday night or a grand gathering on a weekday. The staff are always pleasant and the times I have gone there in a large group they have always moved tables or gone out of their way to make us find a place that we will be happy with.
