The intimacy of the place makes you feel immersed in the show. Highly recommended as a venue to see a wide range of entertainment.

It doesn't look like much from the outside and you need to traipse down into deepest Shepherd's Bush to reach it, but Bush Hall is very beautiful on the inside, with gorgeous stucco'd walls. They seem to attract an interesting roster of quirkier artists, from indie to folk, who don't mind the slightly subpar facilities and occasionally wobbly sound quality. Still, this place has lots of charm and it's a great venue to see a performer like Bat for Lashes, who can live up to the scenery.
Great venue for small bands.

result.name: Battersea Arts Centre
result.address: Lavender Hill, London SW11 5TN, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: The Scratch bar in the Battersea Arts Centre is a fabulous little bar with great staff and a relaxing atmosphere. It's a slight trek from Clapham Junction so is refreshingly not overcrowded, and they have an interesting range of beer at great prices - a pint of imported Kirin Ichiban was only £4! The decor was quirky and comfortable, with a good amount of seating. They were playing catchy old reggae and similar type music all night which made a nice setting for drinks and conversation. The staff were amazingly pleasant and fun. The only drawback was the closing time, but I'm sure that is down to location. I'd definitely go back if in the area.
An amazing creative hub! Really impressed by your work!

Wot? No Fish!!
When writer and performer Danny Braverman inherited a shoebox that belonged to his great uncle Abraham ‘Ab’ Solomons, there was nothing for it but to share its contents with the world. Because inside that shoebox lay a lifetime of memories, an honest expression of love, and a witty and perceptive artistic talent. Uncle Ab had provided a chronicle of married life in London’s East End Jewish community, drawn on little brown wage slips. In Wot? No Fish!!, currently playing at the Battersea Arts Centre, Braverman shares this insight into Ab’s life.

One week in 1926, shoemaker Ab Solomons decided to doodle on the wage slip that he gave to a girl called Celie Brenner. Celie was Ab’s wife, but she was also his muse and his audience. Over the next sixty years, every week, Ab would draw snapshots of their life together. Humorous, tender, sober, even raunchy (!), Ab’s doodles to Celie give a glimpse into their relationship, their faith, and their community. As the years passed and the doodles became detailed miniature artworks, major events punctuate the drawings. Celie and Ab have two children, they survive the Blitz, and their son gets admitted to a psychiatric hospital. Their relationship is tested to the limit and they endure heartbreaking loss, but throughout, Ab continues his pictures for Celie, even graduating to Technicolor on his retirement.

In Wot? No Fish!! Danny Braverman carefully sifts through the 2,500 or so little brown wage packets to present snippets of his great uncle and aunt’s history. Using a projector to show each drawing, Braverman’s one-man show and tell is simple in its structure, taking us from birth to death and everything in between. His show is a mixture of lecture and performance, with Braverman including his audience in the story from the outset: handing out cooked fish balls for them to eat (delicious!) and throwing questions to those watching.

Braverman is an excellent storyteller, knowing how to please and enrapture his audience. He has clearly carefully studied Ab’s drawings, and offers his interpretation of what Ab might have been thinking and feeling. He masterfully presents his chosen selection of wage-packet drawings, turning over the envelopes like a fortune teller revealing life’s cards. Braverman also enlightens his audience, teaching them about religious and cultural traditions.

Wot? No Fish!! is a creation of the Bread & Circuses Theatre Company: a collaboration between Danny Braverman and director Nick Philippou. It runs at the Battersea Arts Centre until 19th July. It’s a fresh love story told through the eyes of a man who understands that every day matters, and is a delight to watch.
Nice spacious café with lots of seats in a nice building. The black coffee I had was nice as well.
An excellent stage space used by local theatre companies, notably the impressive Cygnet Players.

result.name: The White Cross
result.address: Riverside, Richmond, Surrey TW9 1TH, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: You need to have the ribs here. There maybe better ribs in the Greater London area or perhaps the world, but I'm just not sure that's the case. Also the pub is in a great spot, on the river, Meantime on tap with friendly staff to boot. The only downside is that I am getting fat from eating all the ribs.
Best ribs this side of saudi arabia ;-)

A great, spacious pub with outdoor, upstairs and balcony seating. Good atmosphere and riverside views. We didn't eat here but the drinks were well priced and not too expensive! Will be coming back to try the food which looked very tempting!

Lovely big Victorian pub with a terrace overlooking the river and roaring fires inside in winter- beer and wine range is ok and not too pricey, food pretty average, you're here for the setting! Lots of tables but very popular, so get here early or book ahead.

Decent pub food here, my friends particularly enjoyed the ENORMOUS rack of ribs. Beautiful riverside location - my boyfriend particularly enjoys it if the tide comes up and he is 'temporarily marooned' here. Lovely in the winter too, a nice fire and hot chocolate, perfect a walk in Richmond Park,

result.name: The Joiners Arms
result.address: 116-118 Hackney Road, London E2 7QL, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: oh my goodness me! if you are somehow out in Hoxton on a weekend, and you unfortunately pass across this bar, beware, and do not enter!! went there for one pint, to see some friends off and get an early one. spent half an hour standing at the bar, watching people that once were 6 people behind me get served before me... having worked in clubs before, I can appreciate annoyance caused by someone clicking their fingers or shouting at you over the bar- however, finally managing to catch one of their darling bar staff's eyes I asked, as ever, simply and politely if there was any way we could be next, seeing as I only wanted a beer and had been there forever at the front of the Queue, being wilfully ignored by Fanny Cradock and her clan for the previous THIRTY MINUTES- what did I get, but Harris Glenn Milstead, who seemed provoked and furious at my request, DONT I KNOW WHO SHE IS? he, a small, squat creature with bulbous eyes and an attitude rivalling Mussolini firmly put me in my place, when she declared "I decide who gets served next!" At which point I decided to leave the establishment. shame really, I was so full of high hopes. Of a pint of beer and maybe no insults to go with it??! (I know, so bloody naive-And I gave them a fiver to be offended?) If I'd known I'd gone in for some sort of derogatory treatment, I probably would have settled for Browns strip club across the road.I hate it when bitchy queens get all high and mighty. especially when they are being paid £6.50 an hour. I hope you get Ebola. Merry Christmas.
Large space with good choice of beer and real ale . However music terrible early on and inattentive bar staff. Dirty loos,
Atmosphere great, music iffy but good talent. long queses for toilet, but good smoking area (for meeting guys).
Is a very dirty place and make me feel.sick
Fun

result.name: The Cambridge
result.address: 93 Charing Cross Road, London WC2H 0DP, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Had friends from Europe plus my son and his new girlfriend, wanted to be sure we could get a table so we booked in advance, turned up and they'd given the table to someone else. Waitress clearly couldn't give a damn. Ruined our evening, will never go here again.
Very nice pub and perfect location

i was taken there by a friend. i am not a big fan of pubs, i prefer my bars and clubs, however when i went, the place was full and the energy was great. i was happy with the price of the beer and i was also able to try a few beers, which i have never tried before. if you are around and you have no where to go i think you should check this place out and try me what you think... :)

Perfect for pre-theatre dining due to proximity of many West End theatres with many pub classics on offer. My wife and I popped in before seeing the not-to-be-missed "Once" at the nearby Phoenix theatre.

We had not booked so were lucky to get a table in the upstairs dining area. We were greeted and seated by Garry who was an excellent host, juggling all the tables on his own with amazing success. 

The menu is good. We ordered the crumbed prawns & scampi and the steak frites. Both dishes were good value, well presented and arrived very quickly. 

The tables either side of us went for the fish and chips, which looked extremely good. The fish is served in deep fried in beer batter, comes with mushy peas and diners have the choice of a regular or large portion.

We will certainly be returning next time we are in the West End, but will probably use the online booking facility to ensure we get a table.
Found this is a great place for a quiet pint just a short stroll from Leicester Square or Tottenham Court Road/Oxford Street.

result.name: The Grapes
result.address: 76 Narrow Street, London E14 8BP, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
The second pub of the crawl. Beautiful log fire, quick game of scrabble and a nice cosy setting. It's like going back 100 years but in the best way possible. Might have a tickle outside too, the options are endless! 

From board games to antiques, The Grapes has it all. Inflation is yet to hit so a pint is a good price. 

Bonjour to 2 of the other patrons at the pub - there are spare seats on our table if you wish. 

Highly recommend!

One of my favourite traditional English pubs in London, with a wooden balcony right above the river.
As the balcony/terrace is quite small, it does get full very quickly, especially at the weekends, but it’s worth hanging about by the bar until the space on the balcony becomes available.
It’s also very cosy inside and it bursts with history from pictures on the walls. 
Their selection of ales and beers is excellent and priced moderately.

We also had a pleasure to dine in the restaurant upstairs (within the pub) to celebrate my birthday one day. 
My fish tasted very fresh and delicious, and the portion was very generous. It was perhaps a little expensive, but it was totally worth it!
The stuff is polite and attentive.

Oh, and this place is dogs friendly, as there is a water bowl for dogs inside the pub :) Occasionally you can see some happy doggies chilling in the pub, while their owners enjoy the pint :)

There are a couple of bike-racks outside the pub, which is handy for us cyclists.

As Ian McKellen would say, "You shall not pass!"... 
And this was certainly true when trying to get to the bar at the beautiful pub... 

Far too popular for it's size, however that was great once we were served

Lovely cosy pub, with good range of ales. Fish and chips is worth it and you can get a pint portion of whitebait. Service is very good and friendly and there's a great view of the Anthony Gormley sculpture at the back of the pub. The restaurant upstairs is very worth trying as well.

I like the pub. 
LOVE the setting.
Enjoy the beer.
On the whole, the staff are quality.
With one MAJOR exception.
I cannot see why on earth a certain person is working in such a lovely, historic pub.
I would recommend it to anyone, depending on who was working!

result.name: The Hen & Chickens Theatre Bar
result.address: 109 Saint Paul's Road, London N1 2NA, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
Fancy seeing Jimmy Car or alternatively, some theatrical musings for around a tenner? In the upstairs of a pub in Highbury & Islington lies a fifty person TSL fringe favourite, Hen & Chickens theatre. It's a place you'd hardly know was there as the box office seamlessly merges into the pub's bar with little inclination of the dramatic world above...

Read more on this and other independent businesses all across London on the Twenty Something London website!

A friendly theatre bar with a good range of beer. The Hen and Chickens is a one minute walk from Highbury and Islington Station. The theatre sits upstairs and has a capacity of about 60 and has raised seating. The pub gets very busy before and after Arsenal have played.

This is a great place to come for a Sunday afternoon drink and a chat because there’s plenty of seating (and even a super cosy red leather couch if you are lucky enough to snag it first!), it isn’t overly noisy so you won’t have to shout and the bartenders are super duper friendly. (The guy working when I visited was happy to joke with the customers near the bar, which was really refreshing because so many bars lack that kind of engagement with their staff.) From the posters on the walls it looks like they host music and live events, and given the vibe of the pub I bet they’d be really great to see.

I went there to see a play and my friends and I had miscommunicated so that we mistakenly bought eight instead of the needed five tickets on the web. We tried to cancel the purchase or get a refund right after we realized by calling them and again at the door. It was clear to them we had made a mistake and the place was not sold out and they still refused to give us a refund (remember we were still five paying customers coming there). I find that bad customer service and in fact greedy.

P.s.: The play was good though.

Funny little pub, traditional pub I would call it. Went here for a Jimmy Carr warm up gig, he was very funny and its very intimate.

Pub was very hot!

result.name: Avenue
result.address: 7-9 St James's Street, London SW1A 1EE, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: One perfect place to complete your day. They have a great collection of wine that suit every meal that they serve! Elegant, classy and one of the best in town!
Best burger in London and that's saying a lot.......................a big thank you to tom and his team for looking after us, will be back soon.
Just the perfect place to enjoy dinner with family.

This place is practically opposite St James Palace, The large Yellow flag flying majestically to let you know where they are.
Its a very airy venue and has a modernist feel inside. There is a long bar filled with bottles of alcohol. A huge metal murial on oneside and a long wineglass chandelier in the middle. The toilets are tiny, you really have to squeeze in to shut the door.

The staff are friendly and attentive. The cocktail list is full of new cocktails that i have never heard of before. Some of the recipies from America's prohibition period.
I settled on a Senitmenalt Melody and a Carol Channing.

A basket of bread was provided, very tasty but we were not told what they were but looking on the other review here I now know,
I decided on the traditional Prawn cocktail or as they call it a Shrimp cocktail. 
This was delicious but a let down prawn wise. There was a small round of lettuce and fennel topped with what seemed like 4 prawns and marie sauce and grapefruit. However it was actually 2 prawns sliced in half, so not enough prawns to eat with the greens. This dish cost £14.50 thats £7.25 a prawn!!!!!!!!! I might try the clam chowder or smoked salmon next time.

For the main we decided on the Rib eye steak and wow that was superbly cooked. We shared some sides with it of macaroni cheese with truffle oil ( a delight on the taste buds), cayenne fries and hillbilly slaw.

For dessert i settled on good old pecan brownie with ice cream and WOW that was the most moist rich brownie ever tasted. 

I definitely recommend this place for classy American dining at reasonable prices considering where its based.
the perfect places for a NY brunch, first class.

result.name: Underworld Night Club
result.address: 174 Camden High Street, London NW1 0NE, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
I saw Carcass and Corrosion of Conformity in this place... The sound quality is so bad it just spoils everything. The Corrosion of Conformity concert I couldn't finish to watch it because of this. The concert was interrupted twice for equipment failure...
Very bad. Waste of money and time.
Bad sound, dirty and extremely unfriendly staff.

When I am going out I don’t prefer siting in a pretentious bar and just drinking. I enjoy places where I can dance all night. Maybe that’s the reason I like The Underworld so much. Every time I’m leaving this place my feet hurt me … from dancing of course.
The club is not special but the music never disappoints you. The staff is rude and the toilets are disgusting.
Grimey little place. Perfect if thats what you're into

result.name: The Admiral Duncan
result.address: 54 Old Compton Street, London W1D 4UB, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: I've been to The Duncan loads of times. The slightly steep prices cost it that 5th star but I love the atmosphere and never have a problem getting served (and I don't think that's just because of my looks and my skin tight tops). Bette's Boozy Thursdays are the highlight of the week there. I've never been to another bar that had the same great atmosphere, I find the others I've tried in the area (The Village and Ku Bar) just feel dull.
Drinks are high however nice place with fun staff who are helpful.

Be careful of security there I was assaulted by an idiot security guard last night, I went to retrieve my wallet from a freind and i was accused of using the toilet without buying a drink. The guy tried his best to manhandle me out of the bar. My evening was spoiled because of this . I would try the king Edward or Comptons or gay instead

the admiral duncan is that delicate combination of good ole' boy pub and sleazy gay palace. i remember walking in one night and spotting an enormous gay skinhead who made eye contact with me, and immediately made a dash for me, picking me up off the floor like my 270 lb, 6'4" body was a toy. we had a drink and rode off into the london night on his motorcycle. this is the admiral duncan.
the definition of dive bar for the gay crowd

result.name: Old Bull & Bush
result.address: N End Way, Golders Green, London NW3 7HE, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: I went to the Bull and Bush a few weeks ago and had terrible service and an awful meal - I wasn't planning to go back but I then discovered it was under new management so thought i'd give it another shot. So pleased, It is better than ever, fabulous menu, delicious food and good service, without compromising on the warm and comfortable atmosphere they do so well.

The Old Bull & Bush pub is definitely one of my favourite places in London. While it was not exactly close to where I lived or worked, I went there quite frequently with my friends. The best place to sit during winter is on the comfortable sofa next to the fireplace. Enjoying the cosy atmosphere with a glass of red wine - few things can beat that. I have only eaten there once - no complaints about the food, but we usually ordered some snacks with our drinks and I must say they do have a nice selection. Highly recommended!

Staff hopeless if not drunk and course vulgar .food not good .go to the spaniards Inn or the Holly bush anywhere else but here. Staff mess up orders and can't serve properly which is perthetic sad so tragic. What a shame this place has lost its magic it use to be excellent. The food is like school dinners served by morons

Suited as a place to warm up, drink up and and stock up on decent sized food, this spot on top of Golders Green hill is an effort by foot – but also how to earn a thirst. The seating areas range from cosy lounges at the back to wooden seats and tables bear the bar, an the drinks are varied for ale and wine drinkers. The atmosphere is just as warm, with locals lacking any rowdiness.
Nice outdoor patio if you can handle the road noise.

result.name: The Britannia
result.address: 5 Brewers Lane, Richmond, Surrey TW9 1HH, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Went along for Sunday lunch and enjoyed it very much. We had the set meal at £24.95 each and I have to say I think it was very worth while and value for money!
Always excellent service. Superb menu. Ultra-fresh seafood.

AVOID! Came here for a birthday lunch prior to a trip to the cinema. We came here because of the good reviews, however, they are unjustified. First entered to generally surly and uninterested staff even though the place was empty. I ordered a rib-eye steak (well, it was my birthday). The steak was priced at £16.90. A reasonable price considering it was an Angus steak and this place was trying to cast itself off as a bit of a gastro pub, apparently. However, what I got was resembling an old piece of tough leather. It was about the size of a sandwich steak, it was moderately warm on the outside and almost cold at the centre, leading me to believe that this steak had been cooked twice and was simply reheated for my lunch. It was disgusting Very poor all round. Even Wetherspoons serve much better steaks. I know where I will be going in the future. AVOID!
Great food great staff.
Richmond's best kept secret. Great beer garden too

result.name: Ye Olde Fighting Cocks
result.address: 16 Abbey Mill Lane, Saint Albans, Hertfordshire AL3 4HE, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: The Oldest Pub in GB. Excellent food,good beers and spirits and wines.Lovely surroundings with St Albans Lake close by,large open fields with a piece of an ancient Roman wall to have a look at and five minutes away is St Albans Abbey a wonderful ancient building worth a look around.inside full.of history.

I give this pub five stars for its historical value. If you're a local, you won't care, but if you're not from the area, it's a 'must see' on a visit to St. Albans.
Go on a day with nice weather, stoop down to walk in, look around while you're waiting to get up to the bar, and take your drinks to the garden. Hard to imagine that 500 years ago grown men stood upright in the pub without bumping their heads.

I have just got home from being at Ye Olde Fighting Cocks this afternoon and it was a very enjoyable experience. They were so friendly not only to us but also my Great Dane. The food was outstanding and I'm not surprised why it is necessary to book for a meal. The staff were very busy but cheerful and helpful. I would heartily recommend this pub.
Just all in all, a bad pub! Has the potential to be so much better! Don't understand how it's always busy! Extortional wait for food.

Went for Sunday lunch with a group of 7. We turned up at 12:30 and it was fairly quiet - but an hour later it was packed. Service was great and punctual, food was FANTASTIC and atmosphere was lovely and relaxed. Definitely coming back...

result.name: The Kennington
result.address: 60 Camberwell New Road, London SE5 0RS, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: One of my favourite pubs in the area. It's got a great relaxed atmosphere for a weekend drink or a couple in the evening. The food is lovely too and if you head along to the Sunday quiz (it gets quite busy for this) they dish up extra roasties as part of the evening!! It's really well decorated as well and you can tell the owners actually care about their business.

Decent pub with outdoor seating area. They often have good deals & happy hour offers. Great place to waste an afternoon with friends.
Have subsequently had an opportunity to try their Sunday Roast offerings.
We had the chicken breast & Old Spot pork belly & I'd say they were both good but not outstanding. For me the veg was a little over-cooked, but I tend to just wave my broccoli near a boiling kettle. Everything else was good, just, not stand-out / write-home fantastic.
At £20 for 3 courses though, it's really rather decent I think. Portions were also good in thought.
It's proximity to the park makes it perfect for a beer & a bite after a long lazy Sunday in the park.

Definitely recommend the sunday roast. The pork belly is to die for! The sunday night quiz is fun and there are tables outside in the summer. The guys that run the pub are friendly and have always had good service. There are some board games stashed round the corner if you get bored too :)
Good food when we went. Enjoyable, and quite reasonable. The atmosphere could be better, needs heating! Bit of a lack of decent pubs in this area, so this is a well needed option.
Wonderful

result.name: The Golden Lion
result.address: 57 Fulham High Street, London, Fulham SW6 3JJ, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: One of the few real pubs left and not at rip off prices...real friendly banter from a real local. Congrats to Ann and all her staff
This pub is great for catching up with friends and having a good time

result.name: Belgo
result.address: 67 Kingsway, London WC2B 6TD, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
This is a much smaller Belgo than it's cousin at Covent Garden, but it has a much larger Bar area - so if you just fancy a drink this is the Belgo for you! 

Same excellent food as you'd expect from the group but normally slightly less rowdy than Centraal.

Amazing selection of Belgian beers that yes, are expensive, but well worth the price paid. Starters included lobster bisque and croquettes - nothing amazing but decent enough. For mussels we took the traditional, classic and Thai. Happy to report that they were as delicious as they look in pots they're served in. Restaurant is nicely appointed but nothing fancy. Service was friendly and attentive but a bit slow. Very noisy inside. Good place to catch up with family or friends.

Fantastic experience! I went here for my birthday drinks a couple of weeks ago and had such a great time. I called ahead to book space just for drinks and they arranged a nice large table for us by the windows with lots of comfy chairs. I got to try many different kinds of lovely Belgian beers (one of my favourite things to do!!) that they have listed in a handy flip menu, sorted by type and with helpful descriptions. They're not cheap, but worth every penny. And always a nice touch that you get a matching glass for every beer. And to top off all of this they brought over a long slat of drinks for the table as a happy birthday to me - how thoughtful :-) Oh, and they stay open pretty late on a Saturday. Would definitely recommend this place to any beer lover out there, or anyone looking for a nice environment to have drinks with friends.

Probably one of the biggest selection of Belgian beers you'll find outside of Belgium itself - certainly in a bar setting anyway. They even have the ever-popular Delerium on tap :) The beers aren't cheap (we're talking over £5 for a half pint), but luckily the extra alchol content makes up for that. Just watch out - drink these badboys like a British pint and you'll be sleeping in the gutter!
Amazing. Best beer list ever. Like Trappist beers? These guys got you covered.

result.name: Millfield Arts Centre
result.address: Silver Street, London N18 1PJ, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: I love to see a good show a d west side storie is that one

A great view wherever you sit but no leg room. So uncomfortable.
Saw MOTHER GOOSE and was extremely impressed by the cast. They were fantastic. The dancing was amazing and everybody could sing well. Looking out for more productions in the future. xxxxxx
A nice local theatre but a small car park

This year I took my five grandchildren to see both of these shows and they were excellent. The improvements to the theatre make it a lovely venue and this years panto, Aladin, was the best panto Millfield have put on for some years. The performance of Shrek was also brilliant with great dancing and some very talented youngsters. The staff at the theatre are very charming and this all makes for a very nice outing. Well done and excellent local facility that everyone should support.
the above Transit information is wrong. This theatre is in Edmonton, North London and not Fulham Broadway

result.name: The Tabernacle
result.address: 34-35 Powis Square, London W11 2AY, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: I LOVE their Tab Club sandwich - chicken - yes, bacon - yes, caramelised onions - YES please. The whole mix is amazing and really hits the hungry spot. There a few other sandwich options available and all of them are also great. Don't get me wrong, it's not a sandwich bar, they have many other food options, all of them delicious.

Could be a great den of inequity and pleasure if only they had more enterprising management and staff! Great architectural building outside with a dark miserable interior. Food is dull un-eventful, 'Mush' would describe it or two steps away from McDonalds plastic Muck!

I attend the yoga classes regularly and I am very pleased with the way the classes are handled, the fact that it is very clean and the price is good for a dancing class. Also, the facility is great as a whole.

The Tabernacle has long been a centre of the community and is increasingly a centre of excellence, with a very considerate and helpful staff. In the many years I've visited, or promoted events I have not been anything but satisfied with every aspect of positive advice, convenience and support. If I had to say anything negative, it would be the curfew of 10.30pm for live music. But this of course is out of their control, a stipulation of their council licence and very much a consideration for the residential neighbourhood. As always, any opinion is subjective and very much an individual view of moonlight; therefore I encourage anybody to visit and form one's own idea. I doubt you'll be disappointed.
Loved everything about this place. Great sound, friendly staff, beautifully shaped building. Happiness all around.

result.name: The Yorkshire Grey
result.address: 2 Theobalds Road, London WC1X 8PN, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Rickety chairs and tables that are falling apart, a TV screen that is smaller than the one I have at home and installed right under the ceiling so that you get a stiff neck. The bar staff are hit and miss, some are miserable, some charming. The food and drinks prices are jaw-droppingly high. I paid £9.50 for a glass of Sauvignon Plonk. NINE POUNDS FIFTY!!!!! I was so shocked that I handed over the money when really I should've told them to shove it where the sun don't shine. A truly horrible burger that came with EITHER salad OR chips set me back £14,50 because I happend to want both salad AND chips. Turns out the salad, which I had to pay a premium for, consisted of a few lettuce leaves with hardly any dressing on them. As an example, at the splendid Rocket pub on the Euston Road I've paid £5,29 for a truly great burger. That's A THIRD of what I paid at the Yorkshire Grey! I really hope this place goes out of business, it's a rip-off and piss-take from start to finish and should be avoided at all cost. I will certainly NEVER EVER come here again!

Yorkshire grey hosted our half year party. We hired their function room and preordered some food and drink. 

They have a sound system which you can plug your ipod into. Everyone had a great night and commented on what a lovely pub it is.

Very helpful staff and good food, especially the hot dogs. 

Thanks!

pleasant space good booze not too expensive. the food looked good too though i didn't have any.

only black spot was one of the pints myself and a friend ordered was a bit off if just about palatable
Lovely and lively pub.

I have been to this pub many, many times because it's over the road from our office! I would say that i like the decor but it's too busy. The drinks are too expensive and there isn't enough seating. The bar staff are good and they are friendly. 

We had an office party here once and I remember that the party platters were very tsasty. I only tend to go in outside busy hours.

result.name: Goodman's Field
result.address: 87-91 Mansell Street, London E1 8AN, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Was staying in the travelodge across the road and only spotted the Goodmans from the hotel. Had already eaten in the hotel first night (awful) and Goodmans was much better. Seating along the windows on two sides with many other single travelers so didn't feel out of place eating alone. Food and beer was good and very reasonable price, particularly for the area. Won't hesitate to go back.

Good pub, good staff, good everything. I visited 5 times in one week, and when I go back to London, guest where I'll be going again.

The staff looked after me a treat, "Thanks Guys".
The charm of a hospital cafeteria with a pub inside. Some beer specials however and lots of seating. Good for lunch but after sundown avoid if you like being happy

You know Wetherspoons, so you know what you're getting, it is in a good area and since most of the places nearby are expensive, it is probably a good place to start your drinks if you are heading to Tower Hill area.

The place itself is large, only one floor I think...unless there are stairs I've never seen.

The food was good last time I ate, they have free Wifi, and always deals on shots. You know the deal.

Open at the weekend too, which for the area, is an exception rather than the rule as the area shuts down over the weekend.
A big glass fronted Wetherspoons with virtually no atmosphere or character. Ok for an after-work drink or a cooked breakfast, but better pubs are close by for an evening out.

result.name: The Surrey Docks
result.address: 185 Lower Road, London SE16 2LW, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Yes, the place is a bit overpriced; however, it's well worth your time and money. The order came in quickly and the food was really excellent. The five of us really enjoyed the atmosphere and decided to revisit the place on a regular basis. Highly recommended.
Only go there for breakfast occasionally. Dont go alot on there dinners
Only go there now and than staff are friendly pub has good services bit never ate there
Like the food.
It's a Wetherspoons Pub. Same as all the other Wetherspoons pubs out there. Not bad - but never great. So go there for cheap food and pint if you're in the area.

result.name: Lyric Hammersmith
result.address: King Street, Lyric Square, London W6 0QL, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
When in need of a theatre fix the place that’s remained a centrepiece to the Hammersmith community ever since 1895, is well worth a visit. In sum there are three things that make this theatre stand out from the rest. First, the breathtaking main auditorium which contrasts nicely to rest of the building’s modern construction. The story goes that in 1966 after losing funding and having to close, the local community were so determined to keep the historic architecture that they took it down, piece by piece, and saved it for when money came by to put it back together...

To find more unique and independent places why not visit the Twenty Something London website!
I was here for the first time a couple of nights ago and it made me such a big impression... theater is definitely not dead. The performance was excellent and our whole group had an excellent time.

This theatre is world class! They provide great shows, both family friendly and for the more advanced theatre-goers. 
I love the classic interior of the theatre and the contrasting foyer and lobby area. Great staff are always happy to help and squeeze you in even if you're running a bit late!

Also brilliant panto for all the family every Christmas :)

This theatre showcases a lot of new and interesting work from relatively unknown playwrights. I've seen some great pieces here but you often have to take a risk and go and see something unexpected. The theatre itself is nice, but feels a little cramped as you have to go straight upstairs when you come in. There's a nice little roof garden for the summer.
Nice theatre and nice cafe, only thing that isn't nice at all is the way the cafe manager (I think her name is Amanda) handles customers relationships!!

result.name: The Hinds Head
result.address: High Street, Bray, Berkshire SL6 2AB, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Great food. Great staff. Very warm and welcoming. Remembered us the next time when we booked. A guaranteed success of a meal out.

Looking for a place to eat for lunch I realized that Heston's pub was nearby so we thought that we'd give it a try. After a rather confused, and rude, reception from the front of house we were asked to take a seat at the bar whereby we would shortly be escorted to our tables. Some 30 minutes and 2 drinks later we walked out. Couldn't tell you about the food, just that the staff seemed pretty highly stung and certainly did not cultivate a relaxing dinning atmosphere with their obnoxious back and forth with the chef - I get it, you are clearly very important, now please be quiet while I wait for one of your colleagues to acknowledge me as I am starting think that I must be invisible. Don't believe the hype - you'd get a better service at McDonald's.

Today tried to get in monkey island but we could not get in.
Went instead to Hind's Head and had shepherds pie and roast pork.
The shepherds pie was over salted and would benefit from cheese on top.
The waiter warned me the pork would be pink but I told him to bring it properly cooked which he did, I was surprised by the Aunty Betty potatoes.
It is a nice place the beer is good and reasonably priced but avoid the overpriced starters and side dishes. We didn't and it cost over £90 for two. 
All in all Weatherspoon does it better.

If you're in Bray but haven't had the change to remortgage your home to eat in one of the bigger Michelin-star restaurants in town, this is definitely worth a visit. The pub itself oozes character yet lacks pretension whilst the combination of very Heston-inspired cocktails (dry ice on rum, anyone?!) and good, solid British cuisine (including the legendary triple cooked chips) are a winner, whether you've popped in for a summer evening drink or have come in search of comfort food in the depth of winter.
OK, but portions a bit small. Not quite as good as hoped, have been to better pubs.

result.name: Crooked Billet
result.address: 14-15 Crooked Billet, Wimbledon, London SW19 4RQ, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Very nicely renovated, traditional pub. The beer garden is enormous, with lots of picnic tables, deck chairs and heated/covered booths. Great in summer and the colder months. I reserved a table for my birthday drinks and it was a lovely, relaxed day. The classic pub food (fish and chips, burgers) and ping pong meant we stayed from early afternoon to late at night. Have visited again in winter and it's equally great: dark wood, big armchairs, a fireplace and hot mulled cider. Very conveniently located next to Clapton station so a handy meeting place for a quick after work pint or a special occasion.

The quintessential British Pub. My grandfather was registered here as a one-year-old in the 1881 census. G-Grandpa was in with the missus and the lill'un, 'aving a pint when the bleedin census-takers 'unted him down.
Visited here in 2013, 'asn't changed 'tall! Good beer, good conversation, good management (Duncan).

When you're expatriated from the countryside to pursue a career in the city it's easy to become jaded and 'owt right down in the mouth when you're surrounded by urban sprawl with no break for greenery, cows or cosy countryside drinking establishments that writers continue to romanticise over in the trash novels as they did in the great ones. 

Imagine, then, if you will, the soul-nurturing uplift that my girlfriend and I felt when we happened upon this gem just off Wimbledon common. A welcome refuge from a classically hazy autumnal day, this place hit you with the familiar smell of woodsmoke soaked into oaken beams the second you walked through the door. Some jazzy licks fought their way over the chatter and - if you can forget the LARGE number of children in pushchairs - we felt like we'd gone home, if not for a little while.

the drink was good, the bar snacks were awesome, the atmosphere was addictive. We'll be back here before long, and will probably make a habit of visiting anytime we feel that longing for the clean air and bovine companions that any self respecting country bumpkin misses when trapped in the smoke.

Don't get me wrong, I love London, but my roots are out of the city, and this place feels like it's out of the city as well.

Recently had dinner here with my wife and the food was excellent. We used to go to the Fox and Grapes pretty frequently, but since it's "upgrade" and it's no longer a traditional pub we've been trying out other spots around the Village. Crooked Billet has great food, good beer and still has that traditional pub feel about it, plus on nice days you can take your drinks outside and lie on the grass. Will be spending more time in the place over the coming months.
Very cozy and traditional pub. They serve nice food as well for a decent price (£15-20 per head).

result.name: Pillars Of Hercules
result.address: 7 Greek Street, London W1D 4DF, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: My kind of pub. Small, intimate & historical. We got served within seconds of entering in a Saturday night which is bloody amazing. This is one cozy place.
An unassuming - but surprisingly cool - traditional London pub. It is said that slebs can be see here regularly, before local gigs. For those that are interested in that kind of thing.

I have to say that this pub is a normal one. Not my first choice, but when I'm in the area I always visit it. It is close actually to the Covent Garden tube station and the location is one of the positive things that I can share with you, guys.
On Saturday I was there with two of my friends - Josh and Alisha. We've known each other for years. Altogether, we agreed that this is a cosy place. The fact that it is open till midnight on Satuday is a pretty cool one.
I don't like that if you want to check the menu on their website, you have to download a file. I prefer not to, so my visit will be a surprise, for sure.
Excellent pub. Great place to while away an hour or so chatting or surfing.
Unpretentious, cozy (that's code for "tiny"), and a great pint.

result.name: Cape
result.address: 10 Aldermanbury Square, Love Lane, London EC2V 7JQ, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Cheap specials, basic food, with the saddest most miserable and unhappy staff ever. Most of the staff just couldn't really be bothered, new faces every week! Most of the fixtures are falling off the walls. The place is big comfortable and does the job. Food is simply standard.

large bar, upstairs tended to be hired out for private events, the bulk of people stay downstairs. This place can be quite popular on a Thursday and Friday night crowd. It's tends to be favoured for leaving drinks ifor people working in the surrounding area. It can be quite lively and quite packed.

Modern décor, some seating areas and tables , large bar and selection of drinks, friendly and speedy bar staff.
server was slow. prices high. bar man wouldnt take our order - kept insisting we order a bottle. slow slow serivice even when not busy. nothing exciting to justify high drink prices
Great place for casual social meetings. Pleasant staff and very decent food. Prices are proportional to service and atmosphere.
Lots of screens.

result.name: The Brownswood
result.address: 271 Green Lanes, London N4 2EX, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Decent pub, with a pretty good selection of beers and other drinks, and they do really good food too. Especially the fish and chips. Lovely.
Great local pub with good food and an excellent range of draught beers and ciders.
Big beer garden and a very nice selection of beers and ales. Food wise I only had the chunky chips so far, which were good.
Great local pub, I moved nearby 4 years ago and it was a bit of a dump. It was done up a few years ago and is always busy now, especially week nights. Great food especially the fish and chips.
I'm afraid the Brownswood has once again disappointed me when it comes to the service. The food is great and the staff seem friendly enough but waiting nearly 40 minutes for a burger is outrageous.

result.name: Paternoster
result.address: 2-4 Paternoster Row, London EC4M 7DZ, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
After noticing The Paternoster's very generous offer of a free round of Guinness when you booked an area, I reserved a space for myself and a large group of friends for the England v France game at the beginning of the Six Nations. 

Firstly, the service was absolutely excellent. The team made us feel incredibly welcome, were very attentive and most of all, very friendly. The food was absolutely superb as well with every member of the group commenting on it!

In fact, we had such a great time we went back again for the England v Wales game and, yet again, had a fantastic time due to the great work of the staff and the fantastic food.

The proximity to St. Pauls made it a very easy place to find and an excellent meeting point for a large group of people.

It is now my go-to pub in the city and I would strongly advise others to try it!

Best pub for some lunch in the area. I think that the food was the place's strongest side - it was big in portions and delicious. Also, friendly service and fine dining ambiance complete the mix accordingly.
Lovely little quiet spot by St Paul's Cathedral. I liked the statue of the shepherd. Great spot on a sunny day. Some nice restaurants there too.
Expensive if compared to the average of London pubs. Quite wide range of beers. Good atmosphere.
Super nice pub by St Paul's. Got off tube to pee and this pub delivered!!!

result.name: Comptons of Soho
result.address: 51-53 Old Compton Street, Westminster, London W1D 6HN, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: It can get pretty busy here especially on a Friday or Saturday night. I found that it's not really for the 'young crowd' and is generally more chilled out. I usually prefer to hang out upstairs with my friends if I come here. The staff are friendly here and if it's not too busy will have a chat with you too :) I don't really like super loud places that blast music so I can't have a conversation with someone standing next to me, this isn't one of those places, so 5 points to Gryffindor! I mean, Comptons.
Great atmosphere, Great selection of drinks, great staff. Comptons feels very welcoming, drinks are very fairly priced considering central London

Comptons has been around a long time. Whilst other gay bars come and go, Comptons has stood like a castle and symbol to the predominance of the gay scene in Soho. It is an adults bar and the age of the clientele tends to be older than places like g.a.y. It's a great place to meet other men, most of whom pride themselves on their masculinity. You get your mix of bears, some leather men, smartly dressed, older guys and young twinks. Inside, it's a great mix of traditional decor, calm ambience and pre-party atmosphere with DJ's on the weekend. You can sit in comfort up in the lounge and chat, or cruise and mingle with freedom downstairs with decent house music playing in a darker, cruiser atmosphere with disco lights. Whilst some people have moaned about the service, the guys in bar are good looking, genuine nice people. They're a mix of English and other nationalities. Once they've seen your face a few times, their honest friendliness shows through, unlike a fake smiling trolly-dolly! So, I don't accept the poor service comments. If you compare it to other places which can be much slower during busier times, they are not bad at all! It's a great meeting place and its always busy. It's an institution, it's friendly, honest, friendly regulars and most gay visitors first port of call in Soho.

Well what can you say feeling depressed visit Compton's of Soho the bar staff don't know how to say thank you of even smile in fact, I don't even think they want to be there, 
I don't think I have ever seen such depressing staff. , and they even put you change on a tip tray lol
So Xmas cheer at compton's I don't think so !

So if your feeling depressed or just feel like ending your life then visit Compton s of Soho
the bar staff are sure to help you on the way and all they will want is a tip for the service

Used to be a friendly bar were did they find pumped up steroid users ?????

Try some of the other local bars for friendly bar staff 

PS the door staff are friendly at compton's
cool spot to enjoy a beer and have a nice chat with some hunky guy.

result.name: Great Queen Street Restaurant
result.address: 32 Great Queen Street, London WC2B 5AA, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: The atmosphere was brilliant and the staff both welcoming and friendly throughout the evening. The drinks were great, including the cocktails and the red wine. The starters were good, we went for the most out there options, but felt they didn't match up to the main which was incredible. We had the rib steak special to share and it was superb. Highly recommend.

An amazing restaurant with a downstairs bar, this place oozes subtle sophistication with properly thought out decor and a shop front lacking a name. They serve gastro pub food to impeccable standard, with a simple, informal yet informed menu. Don't get put off by the menu. Friendly staff are in the know and on hand to provide in depth explanations, so you can feel a little more comfortable getting your adventure on.

Want to read more about Great Queen Street? Check out Twenty Something London for the full write up.

I was disappointed I ordered a prime rib and got a small piece of meat and did not have a choice of how it was cooked. You also do not get any vegetables as a side. The potato where hand fries not the type of potatoes I expected to be served with a prime rib.

Luckily, the crew was super helpful and knowledgeable and was able to tell me exactly what their best dishes here are.
Their ambience was so nice, rustic, floorboards, plain decor;and admittedly it is a little squashed in. All the dishes brought to the table considered excellent. Pigeon looked like a little chicken, but once you cut into it, the flesh looks and tastes it like a like beef.
The meat was tender and juicy and I had to steal bits when my husband wasn't looking. I had also the plaice and it was the best fish I've had in the UK so far. The daubed was decent but there were other things on the menu I'd go for before ordering that again. Overall despite a little bit of mistakes it was a great meal, definitely will I go back here!

The menu changes on a daily basis depending on whatever's in season, so every meal I've had there has been quite different, although the high quality of cooking has remained consistent. With the dishes on constant rotation though, it's almost impossible to predict when your favourites will come back on the menu again. 

With a focus mainly on meats, it's a good place to bring more carnivorous friends. The lighting's fairly dim so not everyone will be able to read the specials board all the way in the back of the restaurant, but the staff are well-versed in the day's offerings and make good calls on what to try. 

Tables tend to be very small and cramped though, so if you're ordering a few dishes to share you might end up having to play 3D tetris with the plates and bowls.

result.name: Seven Dials Club
result.address: 42 Earlham Street, London WC2H 9LA, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
This place I happened upon as my friend found that they did a quiz. The place is up some stairs, through some doors and is basically a room with a bar.

The place reminded me of a working men's club, in the best way possible, the alcohol was cheap, they had a pool table and the people doing the quiz have probably been doing it for 20 years.

If you are up for a bit of daring to find it and walk in on lots of regulars drinking, it is worth finding it.

You probably won't win the quiz, it was stupidly hard.
Some of the best steaks in London.
Funy

result.name: Gielgud Theatre
result.address: Shaftesbury Avenue, London W1D 6AR, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
Amazingly beautiful theatre located on Shaftesbury avenue. We were sat in the stalls area of the theatre. The only problem with this is that it's flat and the seats are aligned so if you happen to sit behind someone tall or with big hair your view will be slightly obscured. The seats were comfortable with plenty of leg room.

The inside is a bit of a maze, the toilets and bar are behind the stalls area. There aren't enough ladies as always so try to go before you get there

I went to see Strangers On A Train, fantastic gripping play that was well performed. Most suited for a venue like this.

The theatre is quite small which only makes it a more enjoyable experience in my opinion. The staff are friendly and helpful. You can bring your drinks into the theatre area but you must use a plastic container.

We saw Dame Angela Lansbury in Blithe Spirit, the play had some great actors, but Lansbury was the only one to get claps every time she left the stage!

Tip: order your interval drinks at the little stand by the ticket booth when you arrive.

I visited the Gielgud theatre last year to watch Umbrellas of Cherbourg the musical. Amazing interior and the stage and seating was appropriate for viewing the stage.

All staff were friendly and welcoming which is refreshing for Central London!

Facilities such as bar and toilets were clean and there were enough for everyone which = no queues = no missing the First Act!!
Went to see Strangers on a Train, was a great crime drama. Theatre is very nice not so big so you have a good view.

The staff could do a bit of a better job of herding the audience in a....organized manner to their seats (I almost got trampled a few times), but the facilities are very clean and there isn't really bad seat in the house!

result.name: Electrowerkz
result.address: 7 Torrens Street, London EC1V 1NQ, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
A proper venue, this place is the typical, dark, dingy place, with just a random door down a street next to Angel, and it makes it perfect.

They have massive doors between each area and I think depending on the gig, can open them up even more.

They serve Red Stripe by the plenty, which is the go-to beer for gigs, I think they are bigger cans too, so need to carry less around you.

The crowds have always been good, but it will always depend on the band you are seeing, so never saw a bouncer get involved.

If you are off to see a band here, I’d suggest finding it first, then going to the Wetherspoons nearby for pre-drinks.
I've only been once, but I had the time of my life. I'm definitely going to be scheduling another visit soon. I could have definitely used a place like that during my adolescence!
Nowhere quite like it. It has its imperfections, but they're part of the charm.
Dark dingey and dirty, ideal for the kind of events that are held there and lots of fun to be had. lots of rooms, lots of floors etc

I freaking love this place. Lots of floors and lots of rooms with different things in to choose from. If you're done with dancing to the harder stuff, you can go chill out and watch a movie for a while. If you want to dance to something a little different, just shift over to the next room. There are plenty of bars, and I believe you can bring your own alcohol in. I always go for Slimelight, and have been happily surprised to see some of my favourite bands play there for not a whole lot of money.

result.name: The Hop Poles
result.address: 17-19 King Street, Hammersmith, London W6 9HR, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
Moody staff, a smile is not what you will get from these spanish staff. Food was overcooked and tasteless.

Party of 15 will not be returning, managment and staff need sacking and changing!

Have to be honest it was a dire experience through and through.

Usually like this pub, but on Sunday the staff were very sullen. Having bought 2 bottles of wine (not house) at £18.45 per bottle, I then asked for 1 glass of the same wine and a large brandy (not house, but Hennessey or something similar). I was then charged £19 for the 2 drinks. £10 for a large brandy and £9 for a glass of wine !! Sadly will not be using or recommending this pub again.

We hosted a club Christmas Party with The Hop Poles and got both a good price and good service. The bill was split such that food and drinks were paid for separately to make final payments easier. They accommodated for both coeliac and vegetarians and were excellent when it came to change an order that had gone wrong. The pub itself is spacious, has seating of varying type (dining table, sofas, high tables) and a friendly atmosphere.

The Hop Poles is a great place to meet friends for drinks on a weeknight. The bar gets busy after hours but we have always managed to find a seat even if the couches sink a little bit too low. You get so comfortable that you always end up staying longer than planned. There are so many different beers and ciders on tap its easy to want to try them all. If ordering food, they are honest about the wait time and to be quite honest it is worth the wait. If you haven't already been there it is worth giving it a go.
Good ale.

result.name: The New Cross House
result.address: 316 New Cross Road, London SE14 6AF, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: I don't understand how this people manage to hire only rude staff, apart from the bouncers which are always nice. I've been there so many time since it opened years ago and it's my "local" but I can avoid it if I can. the selection of the beer is quite bad, most of it taste of soap and expensive. the garden ouside is cute expecially the building where you can smoke and the whole pub is kind of charming and has been done very tastefully.

I've given the New Cross House a few chances over the last couple of years as it's a nice-looking venue. I've given up now. I've had too many instances of rude staff implying that it's an inconvenience to serve me, massive waits at quiet bars waiting for them to serve me or to bring a coffee to my table. This time the guy even rolled his eyes as he brought a coffee that we waited 15 minutes for on a quiet Saturday afternoon. Not good enough. We'll try Cafe Crema next time!
Great space for a drink or two. The pub has a large outdoor area, with a two story covered brick space. It has a good selection of taps.

Nicely renovated, light and airy pub close to New Cross Gate station. Beautiful tiled walls, leather booths and huge windows. A lot of tables were reserved but we managed to grab one of the booths, which was great for a group. Table service was also a nice touch. The garden is massive and has a brilliant covered area and table football. Loved the crispy oven-fired pizza and local ale selection.
Superb place. Beautifully decorated, fine selection of well kept drinks, delicious food, friendly staff. Well worth a visit.

result.name: Forman's
result.address: Stour Road, London E3 2NT, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Recently, I attended Forman's Restaurant with my wife. We were pleasantly surprised we had feel like at an exhibition. The dishes look amazing, very delicious. Probably the best smoked salmon we've ever tried. You have all my admiration

Probably the best smoked salmon I've tasted in a while. Very subtle smoke flavour that didn't over power the fish. Amazingly friendly staff that made every effort possible and even talked through the smoking room which can be seen through the port holes from the first floor of the restaurant. (Visit - 04/10/2014 Brunch Service)

What an amazing find - this place has exceeded all my expectations!

We were invited to Mark Pearson's art exhibition in Forman's Smokehouse Gallery one evening.

We cycled there and on arrival got a bit confused, as the outside surroundings looked rather industrial and kind of rough, but as soon as we walked into the Forman's Smokehouse, it was like we stepped into a different dimension. 

I loved that there was a window into the room where smoked salmons were drying. There was something magical about that room.

We then made our way to the top floor gallery and roof terrace. The gallery was very spacious with modern furniture, bar, pillars throughout the whole room and absolutely gorgeous view of the canal and the Olympic Stadium through long glass windows.

After viewing the paintings and having a few drinks and canapes in the gallery, we decided to check out the restaurant and bar on the 1st floor. 
Just before we walked into the bar and restaurant area, there was a big glass window into into the smokery, where we could see some people at work preparing salmons for smoking.

We could not resist the temptation and decided to have some food and wine here. Their smoked salmon platter is to die for! It came on a wooden-board with about 8 different types of smoked salmon, including beetroot and wasabi flavorings, and accompanied with mini-blinis and freshly baked bread. We also had a glass of English red wine, which was quite impressive.

The restaurant had a modern and relaxing feel, and it was quite busy with customers. 
We managed to grab a table on the balcony, which had a very cosy and romantic set up with candles on the tables and a spectacular view of the canal and the Olympic stadium. It was perfect, as it was one of the warmest evening in London.

Our waiter was very helpful, knowledgeable and friendly, and gave us some good tips on upcoming events in the area and Forman's Smokehouse.

There is a secured free Wi-Fi available in the Bar and Restaurant area.

I have very quickly become a fan of this place, and i cannot wait to come back soon and introduce this wonderful hidden gem to my friends and relatives.

For those who cycle, there are cycling-racks available inside the car park next to the Forman's Smokehouse ;)
The food and service is very good, however booking a table is a nightmare, nobody seems to answer the phone.... leave a message...and nobody calls you back !
Very easy to order and the food was delivered well packaged and on time. The smoked salmon was delicious and I will definitely be ordering again.

result.name: Town of Ramsgate
result.address: 62 Wapping High Street, London E1W 2PN, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Nice little place on Wapping High St. Long & narrow, with yard at back with small terrace on to river. Dark & gloomy inside, full of atmosphere. Pride & Doom on when we visited. Standard central London pricing = V Expensive!

This is a great little pub, with an authentic feel to it. The history of the place is fascinating, dating back to the 11th Century. During the summer months sitting outdoors at the back overlooking the Thames is a real treat. Pub food, really well put together and reasonably priced. The owners and staff are very friendly and it has recently been sensitively restored to it's last major rebuild as part of the beautiful Oliver's Wharf buliding. Well worth a visit if you're into chilling with a beer, chatting and taking in some ancient parts of London's rich history.
Lovely authentic little pub , the staff is awesome and so is the food , plus they have leffe beer on draught :)

The best of the three riverside pubs in Wapping. Decent beers, good wine selection, and a lovely little beer garden out the back. Sunday carvery-style lunch served by the landlord, with locally-bought meat and veg.

This is a pub that if you are in the area I'd recommend popping in for at least one. The staff are always friendly and it has a feeling that the locals go here but not in a way that you feel you are unwelcome. The bar staff are always friendly and say bye when you leave which I always feel is a nice thing to do.

The pub is quite narrow but long so there isn't the most amount of seating but there is a beer garden out back that looks out on to the river which on a summer's day I imagine is nice view.

They serve a few ales, such as Doom Bar and Youngs, they also have a large selections of bottled beer and the like.

The pub itself is steeped in history, it is supposedly the oldest pub on the River Thames, there should probably be more things inside to read about it all but the website shows it all, which just adds to the charm of the place.

Not had any food here, but the food I've seen all looked very nice and is served by a dumb waiter which always makes it feel quaint.

result.name: Park Theatre
result.address: Clifton Terrace, London N4 3JP, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: Most fabulous venue in North London
Great theatre and love the cafe / bar. Fantastic addition to the area.

What a gem in a changing neighborhood!

Having just finished its run, Daytona certainly filled the seats in a surprisingly well equipped Theatre. 
Boasting two stages (one small one upstairs) and mirroring the ambiance and design of the Donmar, this truly is a clear sign of the rapidly improving neighborhood of Finsbury Park.
The acoustics are wonderful, the production (that I saw), worthy of a place in the West End. But with the added comfort of being situated in an accessible yet settled feeling neighborhood, The Park Theatre is primed to be a great starting venue for productions of fine character.

Park Theatre is possibly the best thing about Finsbury Park now. They have two stages, a smaller one with more experimental performances and a larger one for the headline shows. The theatres are fantastic, small and intimate. They have an interesting selection of drinks, such that it's probably one of the better places to go for just a drink. And for locals, there's even a big discount on a Tuesday!

Gorgeous new theatre in Finsbury Park. Beautiful remodel of the original building into a dynamic and light theatre space. Two full bars, lots of seating pre-show. The theatres are gorgeous, beautifully designed and a dream space for artists. We saw "Yellowface." The production was flawless. 

My only advice would be to have a sign about ticket pick up and perhaps re-jigger the ticket pick up with the bar needs. It was a little tight and confusing at first.

But that is a minor glitch compared to the amazing space, the theatres and the talent.

result.name: The Running Horse
result.address: 38 Bridge Street, Leatherhead, Surrey KT22 8BZ, United Kingdom

indReviews.text:
I had the worst pub experience I have had for a while here.

Some friends and I stopped here after a 100km cycle at 1.45. We ordered food (which at around £12-16 a main was quite expensive but felt like that we had earned it). After waiting around an hour and having ordered another round of drinks we asked where our food was. They informed us that they had not passed that to the kitchen and now it was closed and so we would not be getting any food. They refunded us the money (although not for the extra drinks we had ordered waiting). While this was annoying it was the incredibly rude and dismissive way in which they informed us which made me feel I should write a review. 

This was not an isolated incident on the day as the table next to us only received half their food (not sure how that is possible) and another table didn't receive theirs. The food some people did receive looked ok but it looked a bit overpriced for what it was.

Having lived in Leatherhead most of my adult life there was one place i had never eaten so decided on having a Sunday lunch here.
It was by far the worst meal we have had anywhere period.
The portion size was a joke and the roast potatoes were inedible.
What there were of the vegitables were ok but would have fitted on two forks . 
All in all you would have a better meal by buying a sandwich from a local garage.
Every section is a different menu and motif. The foods are so delicious and great :) This is one the most interesting place I have ever found in. I like it!
Had sunday lunch but it came in children's portions. If you like your food don't go here. White wine was warm and told to add ice!!!
Stopped in for a quick pint while waiting to collect a take away from local curry house. Decent pint of Guinness and friendly staff.

result.name: The Queens
result.address: 26 Broadway Parade, London N8 9DE, United Kingdom

indReviews.text: I had my wedding celebration at the queens so couldn't recommend it more. Relaxed atmosphere, nice crowd, lovely beer garden for summer. Nice range of ales to choose from

The Queens Pub in Crouch End, is my local pub. I've always loved the beautiful surroundings and décor, not to mention the great Roast !
I recently had a private party and the staff were so amazing, they made the whole event very stress free for me and were brilliant. Libby and the team, very professional and accommodating. Couldn't recommended the venue highly enough!

Beautifully-designed pub with a sizeable separate dining area as well as a decent outdoor space as well. The food is on the pricey side but it's good quality. This tends to be one of the first places I think of visiting if I'm going for a tipple in Crouch End.

I think The Queens is one of the loveliest pubs in the area. It has all the charm of an upmarket North London pub with none (or very little) of the pretension. Get there early on a Friday afternoon, if you can, to get a table before the pub fills up. And don't be surprised if you trip over a large dog or toddler on the way to the bar - this is Crouch End after all.
Ornate and historic pub with an excellent range of beers/ales and a sustainable ethos to the restaurant. Unpretentious and relaxed atmosphere make this a winner.
